member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.SchematicsException
member.summary: Represents the exception that is thrown when errors are generated using GTech.Schematics components.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.SchematicsException.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the SchematicsException class. This is the default constructor.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.SchematicsException.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the SchematicsException class with a specified error message.
member.param: A message that describes the error.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.SchematicsException.#ctor(System.Runtime.Serialization.SerializationInfo,System.Runtime.Serialization.StreamingContext)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the SchematicsException class with serialized data.
member.param: The object that holds the serialized object data.
The contextual information about the source or destination.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.SchematicsException.#ctor(System.String,System.Exception)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the SchematicsException class with a specified error message and a reference to the inner exception that is the cause of this exception.
member.param: The error message that explains the reason for the exception.
The exception that is the cause of the current exception. If the innerException parameter is not a null reference, the current exception is raised in a catch block that handles the inner exception.

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTSchematicDataInstance
member.summary: Intergraph G/Technology IGTSchematicDataInstance API.
member.remarks: A IGTSchematicDataInstance object represents a single component view instance, that is, one record from the component view. An object type is used, rather than a recordset, because the IGTSchematicDataInstance object provides access to the Geometry object, and ADO recordset fields cannot hold objects.

member.name: E:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTSchematicDataInstance.PopulateAttributes
member.summary: Occurs when the Attributes collection property is accessed for the first time.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTSchematicDataInstance.Attributes
member.summary: Gets the collection of attributes of a data instance.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTSchematicDataInstance.Geometry
member.summary: Gets or sets the geometry.
member.remarks:
The actual type of the object will be one of the geometry types supported by G/Technology, such as IGTOrientedPointGeometry, IGTPolylineGeometry, or IGTCompositePolylineGeometry. Regardless of which kind of geometry, the returned object will have a Type property to indicate the kind of geometry returned.
If there is no geometry in the component view, the value of this field will be Null. If you set the value of this property to Null, then the geometry of this instance will not be used in generating the schematic.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTSchematicDataInstance.Index
member.summary: Gets the zero-based index of an attribute within a IGTSchematicAttributes collection.

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPlotFrame
member.summary: Intergraph G/Technology IGTPlotFrame API.
member.remarks: A IGTPlotFrame object represents an object or a plot map frame embedded on the plot sheet.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPlotFrame.Activate
member.summary: Method to activate the embedded object or map corresponding to this frame.
member.remarks:
If the frame represents an embedded object, this may enable in-place editing of the object; or it may open the object in another window, depending on the type of the embedded object and the capabilities of the application used to edit it.
If the frame represents a map, then the map is activated in place and you can use G/Technology map-navigation commands such as Pan, Zoom In, and NWArrow on the activated map.
Activate can be called on a plot frame only if its containing IGTNamedPlot is currently displayed in a plot window; otherwise, Activate raises an exception. The object or map is activated in that window.
If another frame is already active, Activate first deactivates the other frame before activating this one.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPlotFrame.Deactivate
member.summary: Method to deactivate the embedded object or map corresponding to this frame.
member.remarks: If the specified frame is not active, an exception is raised. Once deactivated, the object or map cannot be edited until it is once again activated, although it can still be modified programmatically.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPlotFrame.BorderRedline
member.summary: Property to return the IGTPlotRedline object that represents the border of this frame.
member.remarks:
The geometry of the frame is controlled by IGTPlotFrame.Range; accessing the Geometry property of a IGTPlotRedline object corresponding to a IGTPlotFrame will raise an error.
After modifying this property, you must call the IGTApplication's RefreshWindows method to make sure the frame is redrawn properly.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPlotFrame.ClipGeometry
member.summary: Property to return/set the clipping polygon associated with a plot frame.
member.remarks:
Setting this property to a geometry object automatically sets the IsClipped property to True. Setting this property to Nothing automatically sets IsClipped to False.
If this property is set to a geometry type that is not supported, an error is raised and the property is not set.
Although G/Technology does not currently support composite geometries for clipping polygons, write your code to handle IGTCompositePolygonGeometry as well as IGTPolygonGeometry.
After modifying this property, you must call the IGTApplication's RefreshWindows method to make sure the frame is redrawn properly.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPlotFrame.EmbeddedObject
member.summary: Property to return the IDispatch pointer to the embedded object.
member.remarks:
You can use this property to access the embedded object's own automation interfaces. This property can be accessed only if the embedded object's server application is running; otherwise, this property raises an exception.
If you insert the object using a ProgID, the server will probably already be running. Inserting an object from a file, however, typically does not start the object's server. To ensure that the object's server is running, Activate the object.
This property raises an error if the given IGTPlotFrame.Type property is not gtpftObject.
If you modify the embedded object, you must call the IGTApplication's RefreshWindows method to make sure the object is redrawn properly.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPlotFrame.FieldsQuery
member.summary: Property to return/set an SQL string used in processing automatic fields.
member.remarks: Only the first row of results returned by this query is used in processing automatic fields.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPlotFrame.IsClipped
member.summary: Property to return/set whether a plot frame is clipped by a polygon.
member.remarks:
Setting the ClipGeometry property to a valid object sets the IsClipped property to True, but setting IsClipped to False does not affect the ClipGeometry property. It is an error to set IsClipped to True if ClipGeometry is Nothing.
Setting IsClipped to False when ClipGeometry is a valid geometry makes the actual frame geometry the active geometry for the frame, so that the entire map frame or embedded object is visible. Setting IsClipped back to True in that case then makes the clipping boundary active again.
After modifying this property, you must call the IGTApplication's RefreshWindows method to make sure the frame is redrawn properly.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPlotFrame.Locked
member.summary: Property to return/set a flag that, when True, prevents edit operations on the frame.
member.remarks: A locked frame cannot be activated, resized, moved, or deleted by built-in G/Technology commands. However, a locked frame can be modified with custom plotting API.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPlotFrame.Name
member.summary: Property to return/set the name of this plot frame.
member.remarks:
Frame names must be unique within a given plot. The name of an object frame has no significance to any built-in commands, but custom software may want to use it for some purpose.
The name of a map frame is used in automatic field definitions and in NetPlot to specify properties of the map in a remote plot request.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPlotFrame.PlotMap
member.summary: Property to return the IGTPlotMap object corresponding to this frame.
member.remarks: This property raises an error if the given IGTPlotFrame object's Type property is not gtpftMap.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPlotFrame.Range
member.summary: Property to return/set the range of this plot frame.
member.remarks:
The Range property specifies, in paper units, the coordinates of the top-left and bottom-right corners of this frame. This range corresponds to the extents of the underlying OLE object and is not affected by any clipping polygon that may be applied.
The value returned by this property is a copy of the range of the frame. Modifying the returned object will have no effect on the frame unless you set the Range property with the modified object. Furthermore, setting the Range property copies the range values from the specified IGTPaperRange object. Therefore, you can freely modify the IGTPaperRange object after using it to set this Range property without subsequently affecting the frame.
After modifying this property, you must call the IGTApplication's RefreshWindows method to make sure the frame is redrawn properly.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPlotFrame.Type
member.summary: Property to return the type of this plot frame.

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTLineGeometry
member.summary: Intergraph G/Technology IGTLineGeometry API.
member.remarks: The IGTLineGeometry object has two properties that are IGTPoint objects that represent the start point and the end point of the IGTLineGeometry object. The coordinates for the start and end points can be returned or modified through the X, Y, and Z properties of the IGTPoint objects.

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTGeometry
member.summary: Intergraph G/Technology IGTGeometry API.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTGeometry.ExtractGeometry(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPoint,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPoint,System.Boolean)
member.summary: The ExtractGeometry function creates a new geometry object by extracting parts of an existing geometry between two specified points. This function will enable a user to create a new geometry object by extracting parts of an existing geometry between two specified points. This function is intended to be used in commands to digitize using existing geometry.
member.remarks:
Uses positional tolerance.
The start and end points must be on the input geometry. A tolerance is used to determine whether the end and start points are on the geometry. If the distance is greater than the tolerance, an exception is thrown. It is intended that this function be used in conjunction with GTSnapService to ensure that the start and end points are on the input geometry.
The start and end points must be distinct.
member.param: The point from which extraction begins. This point must lie on the input geometry.
The point where extraction ends. This point must lie on the input geometry.

Used to indicate if the points extracted from the start point to the end point should be returned in a descending order in the point list. If this parameter is true, the resulting geometry will be digitized in the reverse order of the original geometry.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTGeometry.GetKeypointType(System.Int32)
member.summary: The GetKeypointType function returns the keypoint type, such as gtkptEndPoint, of a specific keypoint defined by this geometry object.
member.param: The keypoint index, which must be between 0 and 1 less than the number of keypoints defined by the geometry. The KeypointCount property returns the number of keypoints.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTGeometry.GetKeypointPosition(System.Int32)
member.summary: The GetKeypointPosition function returns the position as a IGTPoint object of a specific keypoint defined by this geometry.
member.param: The keypoint index, which must be between 0 and 1 less than the number of keypoints defined by the geometry. The KeypointCount property returns the number of keypoints.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTGeometry.Stroke
member.summary: The StrokeGeometry function returns a stroked geometry using the input geometry.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTGeometry.Copy
member.summary: Returns a copy of this geometry.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTGeometry.Move(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTVector)
member.summary: The Move method moves this geometry object by an amount (delta) defined by a IGTVector object.
member.remarks: Note that the geometry object is modified by this method.
member.param: A IGTVector object defining the distance to move.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTGeometry.Add(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTGeometry,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTVector)
member.summary: Adding a vector to a geometry yields a new geometry that is moved by the delta specified by the vector.
member.param: A IGTGeometry object
A IGTVector object defining the distance to move.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTGeometry.Transform(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTMatrix)
member.summary: Transforms the given geometry using a 4x4 IGTMatrix object. .
member.param: A IGTMatrix object defining the transformation.
member.remarks: Note that the geometry object is modified by this method.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTGeometry.Multiply(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTGeometry,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTMatrix)
member.summary: Multiplying a geometry by a matrix returns a new geometry that is transformed by the matrix.
member.param: The geometry object to be transformed.
A IGTMatrix object defining the transformation.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTGeometry.BreakLinear(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPoint)
member.summary: The BreakLinear method creates two geometry objects by breaking an existing linear geometry object at a specified break point. This function is intended to be used in commands to allow the breaking of existing linework during digitizing so that clean linework, such as nodes at intersections, can be maintained.
member.remarks:
Uses PositionalTolerance.
The break point must be on the input geometry. A tolerance is used to determine whether the point is on the geometry. If the distance is greater than the tolerance, an exception is thrown. It is intended that this function be used in conjunction with SmartSketch to ensure that the break point is snapped to the input geometry.
This method returns an array of one or two geometries. If the break point is on the start point of the input geometry, then one geometry is returned, consisting of the entire input geometry. Likewise, if the break point is on the end point of the input geometry, then one geometry is returned, consisting of the entire input geometry.
member.param: The point where the break is to occur. This point must lie on the input geometry.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTGeometry.BreakPolygon(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTGeometry)
member.summary: The BreakPolygon method creates two polygon geometry objects by breaking an existing polygon geometry object using a specified linear geometry. This function is intended to be used in commands to allow the splitting of simple polygonal areas with a linear geometry -- for example, the splitting of parcel features.
member.remarks:
Uses positional tolerance.
The break points must be on the input geometry. A tolerance is used to determine whether the points are on the geometry. If the distance is greater than the tolerance, an exception is thrown. It is intended that this function be used in conjunction with SnapService to ensure that the break points are snapped to the input geometry.
member.param: The geometry that splits the polygon geometry. The types of linear geometries allowed are line, polyline, and composite polyline. The start point in the linear geometry is assumed to be the first break point and the end point of the linear geometry is assumed to be the second break point. The endpoints of the linear geometry must lie on the polygon geometry.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTGeometry.TrimTo(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTGeometryCollection,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPoint)
member.summary:
The TrimTo method trims the input polyline to one of the crossing_geometries based on the input_point. The polyline is trimmed on the side that has its endpoint closest to the input_point.
The point to which to trim is defined by one of the geometries in the CrossingGeometry collection. The portion of the polyline to trim is defined by a point created by the geometry crossing the closest to the endpoint to trim.
If the input geometry is trimmed, this method returns an array of two geometries. The first element of the array is the input geometry minus the trimmed portion. The second element is the portion of the input geometry that was trimmed. If no trimming is performed, this method returns null.
member.remarks: If the input_point falls on the input geometry between two crossing geometries, nothing will be trimmed and the function will return False.
member.param: Collection of geometries possibly crossing the Input Geometry. Must be a GeometryCollection containing at least one item.
Point defining which side of the InputGeomety to trim.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTGeometry.ExtendTo(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTGeometryCollection,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPoint)
member.summary: The ExtendTo function extends the input polyline to one of the target geometries. The extension is oriented at the angle of the segment from which the extension is added. If an extension is made, this function returns an array of two elements. The first element is the extended geometry, while the second element is the extension that was added (a two-point polyline).
member.remarks:
The geometry must be a polyline.
The target_geometries must be a IGTGeometryCollection containing at least one item.
member.param: IGTPoint defining which side of the InputGeomety to extend.
Geometry collection to which to possibly extend.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTGeometry.CreateOffsetGeometries(System.Double)
member.summary: Creates parallel geometries to the right and left of the input geometry that are offset by a given distance. Right and left are defined by the direction of the points of the input geometry.
member.remarks:
If offset geometries can be created, then an array of 2 elements is returned. The left geometry is the first element (index 0) and the right geometry is the second element (index 1). If no offset geometries can be created, the function returns null.
The input geometry must be a polyline, composite polyline, polygon, or composite polygon.
The returned geometries may not be the same type of geometry as the input geometry. It is possible that the input of a simple polyline could produce a composite polyline output, or that the input of a composite polyline could produce a simple polyline output. The same is true for polygons.
If the input geometry is complex enough (has self-intersections, near self-intersections, or multiple sharp angles), then the output can be a GeometryCollection.
member.param: Distance from the input geometry at which to create the new geometry.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTGeometry.CopyGeometryParallel(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPoint,System.Double)
member.summary: Creates parallel geometry to the right or the left of the input geometry, given an offset distance. The input point defines the side to which to copy parallel. If no offset geometry can be created, the function returns null.
member.remarks: The InputGeometry must be either a polygon, composite polygon, polyline, composite polyline, or an arc.
member.param: Point defining which side of the geometry to create the parallel geometry.
Distance from the input geometry at which to create the new geometry.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTGeometry.Type
member.summary: The Type property returns a string indicating the type of geometry. The strings returned by this property are enumerated in the GTGeometryTypeConstants class. For example, IGTArcGeometry.Type returns "ArcGeometry".

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTGeometry.Range
member.summary: Returns the geometric range of a geometry object.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTGeometry.KeypointCount
member.summary: Returns the number of keypoints defined by the given geometry object. Keypoints are vertices or significant points on a geometry that define it's shape.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTGeometry.FirstPoint
member.summary: Returns the first point of the geometry. Typically, this would be the first point that is drawn when the geometry is displayed. It is generally also the same as keypoint zero. For geometries consisting of a single point (e.g., IGTOrientedPointGeometry), FirstPoint returns that point.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTGeometry.LastPoint
member.summary: Returns the last point of the geometry. Typically, this would be the last point that is drawn when the geometry is displayed. It is generally also equivalent to the last keypoint. An exception to this rule is a boundary geometry; in that case, this is the last point of the exterior.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTLineGeometry.Start
member.summary: Returns or sets the starting point of the line.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTLineGeometry.End
member.summary: Returns or sets the ending point of the line.

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTCUService
member.summary: Intergraph G/Technology IGTCUService API.
member.remarks: The IGTCUService object allows compatible units (CUs) to be filtered, selected, and processed for a given feature

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTCUService.Description(System.String)
member.summary: Method to return the description of a given CU. This definition comes from the work management system tables where the CU data is stored.
member.param: String representing a normal CU or a macro CU.
member.remarks: If the CUIdentifier is not found, an error will be raised to the calling routine.
member.returns: The description of a given CU.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTCUService.Selection(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Method to interactively execute CU Selection.
member.param: Specifies if the CUs being added are primary or ancillary CUs. For primary CUs to be displayed, the Primary parameter for this method should be passed as True or -1. For ancillary CUs, this parameter should be passed as False or 0.
member.remarks:
Default values 1, string.Empty and string.Empty are used for Occurrence, Keyword and Value.
If multiple features are defined inside the IGTKeyObjects collection, then the CU Selection dialog box will be displayed once for each feature being processed. In this case, the feature name and feature ID will be displayed on the dialog box as it is displayed to the user.
This method returns a status that indicates whether the user dismissed the CU Selection dialog box by clicking OK or by clicking Cancel. A value of 1 means the user clicked OK; a value of 2 means the user clicked Cancel.
If the dialog box is displayed multiple times because the IGTKeyObjects collection contains more than one GTKeyObject, the user can click OK to dismiss some of the dialog instances and Cancel to dismiss others. In this case, the status returned will be the OK or Cancel status of the last dialog box shown.
The number of Keywords and the number of Values supplied must match. If they do not, an error message will be displayed and the CU Selection dialog box will not be displayed.
If the Keywords and Values parameters are passed, then the CUs displayed on the dialog box for the features specified in the IGTKeyObjects collection will be pre-filtered.
Keywords and values will be validated. Any invalid keywords or invalid values will result in an error message being raised, and the CU Selection dialog box will not be displayed.
The following SQL statements can be used to find specific keywords for a given feature (facility):
STORMS
SELECT * FROM TWMFACKEYWORDTYPE WHERE CD_FACILITY = [Facility Name];
LOGICA
SELECT * FROM CU_CATEGORY_ATTRIBUTE where CU_CATEGORY_CODE = [Facility Name];
The following SQL statements can be used to find specific values possible for keywords:
STORMS
SELECT * FROM TWMKEYWORD WHERE TP_KEYWORD = [Keyword];
LOGICA
SELECT * FROM CU_ATTRIBUTE_VALUE WHERE CU_ATTRIBUTE_CODE = [Keyword] AND CU_CATEGORY_CODE = [Facility];
When filtering ancillary CUs, the Keywords parameter may also contain one first level filter for each distinct feature type. No value item should be supplied in the Values parameter for first level filters. Thus, the Keywords array will contain more items than the Values array.
The following queries can be used to find first level filters for a given Feature (Facility)
STORMS
SELECT * FROM TWMFACILITYXREF WHERE CD_FACILITY = [Facility Name];
LOGICA
SELECT * FROM G3E_LOGICACUXREF WHERE G3E_FEATURENAME = [Facility Name];
If first level filters are included, they can be anywhere in the Keywords array. As they are identified, they will be removed from the Keywords array, leaving just keywords. Once all of the first level keywords have been removed, the remaining keywords and values will be paired together based on the position of each in the arrays. So the value at array location 1 will be paired with the keyword at array location 1. If the keywords and values are not paired correctly, then the values will be considered as invalid and an error message will be displayed. If the number of remaining keywords does not match the number of values, then an error message will be displayed.
The CUs selected will be checked for Macro expansion.
If the CU component being populated is defined as a repeating component, then the user will be prompted for the quantity of this CU to be added. New CU records will be created, based on the quantity specified.
For STORMS processing, if an application dependency exists for this CU, then the Application Dependency dialog will be displayed to the user for population of these values.
If the CU identifier being added is a primary CU, then static attributes will be processed.
If the CU component being populated is a non-repeating component, and a CU is already defined for the feature, then this method will overwrite the existing CU information and processing will be similar to the Replace Method. No new CU record will be created in this case.
member.returns: A value of 1 which means the user clicked OK; a value of 2 which means the user clicked Cancel.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTCUService.Selection(System.Boolean,System.Int16)
member.summary: Method to interactively execute CU Selection.
member.param: Specifies if the CUs being added are primary or ancillary CUs. For primary CUs to be displayed, the Primary parameter for this method should be passed as True or -1. For ancillary CUs, this parameter should be passed as False or 0.

Shows application dependencies, if any, associated with this CU instance. Like the Keywords parameter, this parameter allows CUs to be pre-filtered on the dialog box. Calling the Selection method without an Occurrence value or with an Occurrence value of -1 will display the CU Selection dialog box so that CUs can be selected interactively. Application dependencies will be displayed only if an Occurrence other than -1 is specified and the CU is an ancillary CU. You will not be able to reselect the ancillary CU value through the GUI. If an Occurrence other than -1 is specified and the CU is a primary CU, the CU Selection dialog box will be displayed first and then the application dependency dialog will appear if the database is configured for application dependencies. If the feature is defined to have application dependencies for this CU type (primary or ancillary), but no application dependencies exist for this CU occurrence, then a message will be displayed stating that this CU does not have any application dependencies. This preserves the current implementation of the CU Selection dialog box when invoked from Feature Explorer.
member.remarks:
Default values string.Empty and string.Empty are used for Keyword and Value.
If multiple features are defined inside the IGTKeyObjects collection, then the CU Selection dialog box will be displayed once for each feature being processed. In this case, the feature name and feature ID will be displayed on the dialog box as it is displayed to the user.
This method returns a status that indicates whether the user dismissed the CU Selection dialog box by clicking OK or by clicking Cancel. A value of 1 means the user clicked OK; a value of 2 means the user clicked Cancel.
If the dialog box is displayed multiple times because the IGTKeyObjects collection contains more than one GTKeyObject, the user can click OK to dismiss some of the dialog instances and Cancel to dismiss others. In this case, the status returned will be the OK or Cancel status of the last dialog box shown.
The number of Keywords and the number of Values supplied must match. If they do not, an error message will be displayed and the CU Selection dialog box will not be displayed.
If the Keywords and Values parameters are passed, then the CUs displayed on the dialog box for the features specified in the IGTKeyObjects collection will be pre-filtered.
Keywords and values will be validated. Any invalid keywords or invalid values will result in an error message being raised, and the CU Selection dialog box will not be displayed.
The following SQL statements can be used to find specific keywords for a given feature (facility):
STORMS
SELECT * FROM TWMFACKEYWORDTYPE WHERE CD_FACILITY = [Facility Name];
LOGICA
SELECT * FROM CU_CATEGORY_ATTRIBUTE where CU_CATEGORY_CODE = [Facility Name];
The following SQL statements can be used to find specific values possible for keywords:
STORMS
SELECT * FROM TWMKEYWORD WHERE TP_KEYWORD = [Keyword];
LOGICA
SELECT * FROM CU_ATTRIBUTE_VALUE WHERE CU_ATTRIBUTE_CODE = [Keyword] AND CU_CATEGORY_CODE = [Facility];
When filtering ancillary CUs, the Keywords parameter may also contain one first level filter for each distinct feature type. No value item should be supplied in the Values parameter for first level filters. Thus, the Keywords array will contain more items than the Values array.
The following queries can be used to find first level filters for a given Feature (Facility)
STORMS
SELECT * FROM TWMFACILITYXREF WHERE CD_FACILITY = [Facility Name];
LOGICA
SELECT * FROM G3E_LOGICACUXREF WHERE G3E_FEATURENAME = [Facility Name];
If first level filters are included, they can be anywhere in the Keywords array. As they are identified, they will be removed from the Keywords array, leaving just keywords. Once all of the first level keywords have been removed, the remaining keywords and values will be paired together based on the position of each in the arrays. So the value at array location 1 will be paired with the keyword at array location 1. If the keywords and values are not paired correctly, then the values will be considered as invalid and an error message will be displayed. If the number of remaining keywords does not match the number of values, then an error message will be displayed.
The CUs selected will be checked for Macro expansion.
If the CU component being populated is defined as a repeating component, then the user will be prompted for the quantity of this CU to be added. New CU records will be created, based on the quantity specified.
For STORMS processing, if an application dependency exists for this CU, then the Application Dependency dialog will be displayed to the user for population of these values.
If the CU identifier being added is a primary CU, then static attributes will be processed.
If the CU component being populated is a non-repeating component, and a CU is already defined for the feature, then this method will overwrite the existing CU information and processing will be similar to the Replace Method. No new CU record will be created in this case.
member.returns: A value of 1 which means the user clicked OK; a value of 2 which means the user clicked Cancel.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTCUService.Selection(System.Boolean,System.Int16,System.String)
member.summary: Method to interactively execute CU Selection.
member.param: Specifies if the CUs being added are primary or ancillary CUs. For primary CUs to be displayed, the Primary parameter for this method should be passed as True or -1. For ancillary CUs, this parameter should be passed as False or 0.

Shows application dependencies, if any, associated with this CU instance. Like the Keywords parameter, this parameter allows CUs to be pre-filtered on the dialog box. Calling the Selection method without an Occurrence value or with an Occurrence value of -1 will display the CU Selection dialog box so that CUs can be selected interactively. Application dependencies will be displayed only if an Occurrence other than -1 is specified and the CU is an ancillary CU. You will not be able to reselect the ancillary CU value through the GUI. If an Occurrence other than -1 is specified and the CU is a primary CU, the CU Selection dialog box will be displayed first and then the application dependency dialog will appear if the database is configured for application dependencies. If the feature is defined to have application dependencies for this CU type (primary or ancillary), but no application dependencies exist for this CU occurrence, then a message will be displayed stating that this CU does not have any application dependencies. This preserves the current implementation of the CU Selection dialog box when invoked from Feature Explorer.

One or more keywords defined inside the work management system as facility keywords. The number of Keywords and the number of Values must match. This parameter allows CUs to be pre-filtered by keyword on the dialog box.
member.remarks:
Default value string.Empty is used for Value.
If multiple features are defined inside the IGTKeyObjects collection, then the CU Selection dialog box will be displayed once for each feature being processed. In this case, the feature name and feature ID will be displayed on the dialog box as it is displayed to the user.
This method returns a status that indicates whether the user dismissed the CU Selection dialog box by clicking OK or by clicking Cancel. A value of 1 means the user clicked OK; a value of 2 means the user clicked Cancel.
If the dialog box is displayed multiple times because the IGTKeyObjects collection contains more than one GTKeyObject, the user can click OK to dismiss some of the dialog instances and Cancel to dismiss others. In this case, the status returned will be the OK or Cancel status of the last dialog box shown.
The number of Keywords and the number of Values supplied must match. If they do not, an error message will be displayed and the CU Selection dialog box will not be displayed.
If the Keywords and Values parameters are passed, then the CUs displayed on the dialog box for the features specified in the IGTKeyObjects collection will be pre-filtered.
Keywords and values will be validated. Any invalid keywords or invalid values will result in an error message being raised, and the CU Selection dialog box will not be displayed.
The following SQL statements can be used to find specific keywords for a given feature (facility):
STORMS
SELECT * FROM TWMFACKEYWORDTYPE WHERE CD_FACILITY = [Facility Name];
LOGICA
SELECT * FROM CU_CATEGORY_ATTRIBUTE where CU_CATEGORY_CODE = [Facility Name];
The following SQL statements can be used to find specific values possible for keywords:
STORMS
SELECT * FROM TWMKEYWORD WHERE TP_KEYWORD = [Keyword];
LOGICA
SELECT * FROM CU_ATTRIBUTE_VALUE WHERE CU_ATTRIBUTE_CODE = [Keyword] AND CU_CATEGORY_CODE = [Facility];
When filtering ancillary CUs, the Keywords parameter may also contain one first level filter for each distinct feature type. No value item should be supplied in the Values parameter for first level filters. Thus, the Keywords array will contain more items than the Values array.
The following queries can be used to find first level filters for a given Feature (Facility)
STORMS
SELECT * FROM TWMFACILITYXREF WHERE CD_FACILITY = [Facility Name];
LOGICA
SELECT * FROM G3E_LOGICACUXREF WHERE G3E_FEATURENAME = [Facility Name];
If first level filters are included, they can be anywhere in the Keywords array. As they are identified, they will be removed from the Keywords array, leaving just keywords. Once all of the first level keywords have been removed, the remaining keywords and values will be paired together based on the position of each in the arrays. So the value at array location 1 will be paired with the keyword at array location 1. If the keywords and values are not paired correctly, then the values will be considered as invalid and an error message will be displayed. If the number of remaining keywords does not match the number of values, then an error message will be displayed.
The CUs selected will be checked for Macro expansion.
If the CU component being populated is defined as a repeating component, then the user will be prompted for the quantity of this CU to be added. New CU records will be created, based on the quantity specified.
For STORMS processing, if an application dependency exists for this CU, then the Application Dependency dialog will be displayed to the user for population of these values.
If the CU identifier being added is a primary CU, then static attributes will be processed.
If the CU component being populated is a non-repeating component, and a CU is already defined for the feature, then this method will overwrite the existing CU information and processing will be similar to the Replace Method. No new CU record will be created in this case.
member.returns: A value of 1 which means the user clicked OK; a value of 2 which means the user clicked Cancel.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTCUService.Add(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Method to Add a Primary or Ancillary CU.
member.param: IDs of one or more CUs being added. If a CU being added is a primary CU, then static attributes will be processed. Multiple CUs can be passed as a comma-delimited string of CUs, or they can be passed as a variant array of strings.

Specifies if the CUs being added are primary or ancillary CUs. If the Primary parameter is True, the CUs will be mapped onto the features inside the IGTKeyObjects collection using the CU facility name and feature numbers on each IGTKeyObject. If a match is not found, an error will be raised to the calling routine. If the Primary parameter is False, the CUs will be mapped onto the first feature inside the IGTKeyObjects collection. If the Primary parameter is True, the CUs can be applied to multiple IGTKeyObjects, based on the facility-to-feature mappings. So the CUs will be applied to the features they are defined for. If the Primary parameter is False, the CUs will only be applied to the first IGTKeyObject. This is because ancillary CUs do not carry specific facility-to-feature mappings like primary CUs.
member.remarks:
The CUs will be added to the features defined in the IGTKeyObjects collection.
This method can display the following dialog boxes:
Select CU Quantity
Application Dependency Properties
For STORMS processing, if an application dependency exists for this CU, then the Application Dependency Properties dialog box will be displayed to the user for population of these values.
Each CU will be checked for macro expansion.
If the CU component being populated is defined as a repeating component, the user will be prompted for the quantity of this CU to be added. New CU records will be created based on the quantity specified.
If the CU component being populated is a non-repeating component, and a CU is already defined for the feature, this method will overwrite the existing CU information and processing will be similar to the Replace Method. No new CU record will be created in this case.
If the CU component being populated is a non-repeating component, and multiple CU values are specified in the CUIdentifiers parameter, then the last CU in the parameter is the one that gets assigned to the feature.
For processing this method, the value of CUValidation in G3E_STRORMSIFACE table must be 1 and G3E_FEATURE.G3E_NAME must be populated in datasets that have a work management system such as STORMS or Logica defined.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTCUService.Delete(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Method to delete an existing CU.
member.param: ID of the CU being deleted. If the CUIdentifier being deleted is a primary CU, then static attributes will be processed. The CUIdentifiers parameter can contain one or more CU values.
Specifies if the CUs being added are primary or ancillary CUs.
member.remarks:
Default value 1 is used for Occurrence.
Calling this method will delete the CU attribute from the feature. This method also cleans up application dependencies for STORMS and other CU-related components from Logica that are tied to the CU being deleted.
If the CU component to be cleaned up is optional, the instances will be deleted. If the CU component to be cleaned up is required and this is not the last instance of this component, then the instance will be deleted. If this is the last instance of a required CU component, the instance will not be deleted. Instead, the CU attributes for the CU identifier, macro CU, usage, and quantity will be nulled out.
If the CU being deleted is a primary CU, the static attributes associated with this CU will be left as is.
If Delete is called and more than one IGTKeyObject has been specified, an error will be raised.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTCUService.Delete(System.String,System.Boolean,System.Int16)
member.summary: Method to delete an existing CU.
member.remarks:
Calling this method will delete the CU attribute from the feature. This method also cleans up application dependencies for STORMS and other CU-related components from Logica that are tied to the CU being deleted.
If the CU component to be cleaned up is optional, the instances will be deleted. If the CU component to be cleaned up is required and this is not the last instance of this component, then the instance will be deleted. If this is the last instance of a required CU component, the instance will not be deleted. Instead, the CU attributes for the CU identifier, macro CU, usage, and quantity will be nulled out.
If the CU being deleted is a primary CU, the static attributes associated with this CU will be left as is.
If Delete is called and more than one IGTKeyObject has been specified, an error will be raised.
member.param: ID of the CU being deleted. If the CUIdentifier being deleted is a primary CU, then static attributes will be processed. The CUIdentifiers parameter can contain one or more CU values.
Specifies if the CUs being added are primary or ancillary CUs.

If the CU being deleted is an ancillary macro CU and an Occurrence value is specified, then only the specified instance of the macro CU will be cleaned up. If the CU being deleted is an ancillary macro CU and no Occurrence value is specified, then all the CUs associated with this macro will be cleaned up. If the CU being deleted is a primary macro CU, then all the CUs and related components associated with this macro will be cleaned up. The Occurrence parameter will be ignored. This means that one individual occurrence or instance of a primary macro CU cannot be deleted. For non-macro CUs, if the Occurrence parameter is specified, then only this occurrence (G3E_CID) of this CU will be cleaned up; otherwise all CUs that match the CUIdentifier parameter will be cleaned up.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTCUService.Replace(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Method to replace an existing CU with another CU value.
member.param: ID of the CU being replaced. If the CU component being replaced is defined as a repeating component, then the user will be prompted for the quantity of this CU to be added. If the ExistingCUIdentifier is a macro CU, the macro will be cleaned up according to the rules laid out in the Delete method for macro cleanup.
ID of the CU replacing the existing one. The NewCUIdentifier will be checked for macro expansion.
Specifies if the CUs being added are primary or ancillary CUs.
member.remarks:

For STORMS processing, if an application dependency exists for this CU, then the Application Dependency Properties dialog box will be displayed for population of these values.
If Replace is called and more than one IGTKeyObject has been specified, an error will be raised.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTCUService.Validate
member.summary: Method to validate CU and static attribute values.
member.remarks:
This method validates the feature within the IGTKeyObjects collection to make certain that all the static attributes for the primary CUs are consistent. If they are not, an ADO recordset listing the feature's G3E_FID and CUIdentifier values that are inconsistent will be returned.
The current static attribute values and the expected values (based upon the CUIdentifier) will also be returned inside this recordset.
The format of the recordset is as follows:
FEATURE_NAME Username of the feature.
G3E_FID Feature instance.
COMPONENT_NAME Username of the CU component record.
G3E_CID CU component instance.
CU_IDENTIFIER The CU value.
STATIC_ATTRIBUTE_NAME Username of the static attribute field.
CURRENT_ATTRIBUTE_VALUE The value stored in the static attribute.
EXPECTED_ATTRIBUTE_VALUE The value expected for the static attribute.
If Validate is called and more than one IGTKeyObject has been specified, an error will be raised.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTCUService.DataContext
member.summary: Property to set the IGTDataContext object.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTCUService.KeyObjects
member.summary: Property KeyObjects provides the collection of IGTKeyObjects for the features being populated and processed with CU data.
member.remarks:
Selection and Add are the only methods that can process multiple IGTKeyObjects, specifically to support the industryware Staking Sheet command. Otherwise, only the first IGTKeyObject inside the collection will be processed.
Example
If a switch gear or other placement configuration with multiple features is being processed, then the IGTKeyObject for each feature would be included inside the IGTKeyObjects collection.
Calling the Selection or Add methods with multiple CUs would cause a mapping to occur between the CUs' facility definitions from the work management tables and the G3E_FEATURE.G3E_NAME for the features defined inside the IGTKeyObject.
If multiple instances of one feature type were defined inside the IGTKeyObjects collection, then the CU value mapped to this feature would be applied to each instance of the feature type (IGTKeyObject).
Macro CUs cannot contain CUs for multiple feature definitions. The macro will be expanded and processed only against the feature that maps to the facility defined for the macro CU itself.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTClassFactory.Create``1(System.Object[])
member.summary:
Method to create an instance of a public Intergraph G/Technology class given an interface type.
Following public Intergraph G/Technology class objects can be created using GTClassFactory.Create in more than one way:
IGTPoint
IGTVector
IGTSegment
IGTSegmentPoint
IGTMatrix
Examples :
IGTPoint type can be created using the following ways:
IGTPoint oPointA = GTClassFactory.Create<IGTPoint>() or IGTPoint oPointB = GTClassFactory.Create<IGTPoint>(20,30,40) or IGTPoint oPointC = GTClassFactory.Create<IGTPoint>(oPointA)
IGTVector type can be created using the following ways:
double i = 1, I component value of the GTVector object. double j = 0, J component value of the GTVector object. double k = 0, K component value of the GTVector object. IGTVector oVectorA = GTClassFactory.Create<IGTVector>() or IGTVector oVectorB = GTClassFactory.Create<IGTVector>(i,j,k) or IGTVector oVectorC = GTClassFactory.Create<IGTVector>(oVectorA)
IGTSegment type can be created using the following ways:
IGTPoint oBeginPoint = GTClassFactory.Create<IGTPoint>(), IGTPoint oEndPoint = GTClassFactory.Create<IGTPoint>(), bool is_extended = false/true - indicates whether the line should be extended infinitely in both directions. IGTSegment oSegment = GTClassFactory.Create<IGTSegment>() or IGTSegment oSegment = GTClassFactory.Create<IGTSegment>(oBeginPoint,oEndPoint) or IGTSegment oSegment = GTClassFactory.Create<IGTSegment>(oBeginPoint,oEndPoint,is_extended)
IGTSegmentPoint type can be created using the following ways:
IGTPoint oPoint = GTClassFactory.Create<IGTPoint>(), IGTSegmentPoint oSegmentPoint = GTClassFactory.Create<IGTSegmentPoint>() or IGTSegmentPoint oSegmentPoint = GTClassFactory.Create<IGTSegmentPoint>(oPoint,GTSegmentPointType)
IGTMatrix type can be created using the following ways:
IGTMatrix oMatrixA = GTClassFactory.Create<IGTMatrix>() or IGTMatrix oMatrixB = GTClassFactory.Create<IGTMatrix>(oMatrixA)
member.typeparam: Type of a public Intergraph G/Technology object to be created.
member.param: A variable object array consisting of list of arguments.
member.returns: Instance of a public Intergraph G/Technology object.

member.remarks:
If the interface does not call this method, the Construction Aids control is not shown. Thus, no construction aids are available to the user.
Before calling this method, the interface must set or create the geometry on the GTGeometryConstructionService, index of which is passed in the GeometryIndex parameter.
Construction aids cannot be used to specify the rotation of oriented point geometries and text point geometries. They can be used only to specify their origin. Therefore, construction aids should be disabled programmatically while the user interactively specifies the rotation.

member.remarks: IGTSchematicAttributes is a collection object that provides access to the columns of the component view associated with a IGTSchematicDataInstance. There is one IGTSchematicAttribute member of this collection for each field in the component view record (except for the geometry).

If an attribute already exists with the specified ColumnName as its ColumnName property, the Add method raises an exception and the collection is not modified.
The Add method raises an exception if it is called for the NetworkAttributes collection of a IGTSchematicElement.

member.param: Index of the network element. Can be between 1 and the number of elements in the collection, or it can be a string specifying the ColumnName of the required attribute.

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPlotRedlines
member.summary: Intergraph G/Technology IGTPlotRedlines API.
member.remarks:
The IGTPlotRedlines collection class represents a collection of redline elements specific to a single IGTNamedPlot object. The collection may represent all redline elements or only elements of a specific type, such as linear redline elements.
The IGTNamedPlot.GetRedlines method is used to obtain a collection of redline elements. Unlike the IGTPlotWindows or IGTMapWindows collections, IGTPlotRedlines is not a snapshot collection; it always represents the current state of the specified plot. Therefore, a given IGTPlotRedlines collection may return different information at different times during a session if the collection exists while other redline modifications are performed.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPlotRedlines.Add(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPlotRedline)
member.summary: Method to add a IGTPlotRedline object to the collection.
member.param: IGTPlotRedline object which is to be added to the collection.
member.exception: Thrown when IGTPlotRedline is Null.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPlotRedlines.Item(System.Int32)
member.summary: Property to return a specific IGTPlotRedline in the collection.
member.param: Index to the IGTPlotRedline.
member.exception: Thrown when index is out of range.

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTLocateService
member.summary: Intergraph G/Technology IGTLocateService API.
member.remarks:
The IGTLocateService object contains methods for locating objects within a specified radius from a locate point. The locate can be restricted to a maximum number of candidates and can use the PickQuick dialog box for the selection of a subset of the located objects.
The IGTLocateService is retrieved from a IGTMapWindow object. Each of the IGTLocateService methods operates on that map window.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTLocateService.Locate(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPoint,System.Int32,System.Int16,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTSelectionTypeConstants)
member.summary: Method to return a set of IGTDDCKeyObjects given a geographic point.
member.param: The real world coordinate value (IGTPoint) where the center of the locate will originate.

The locate tolerance used by the Locate method. The locate tolerance is a square: its center is the input WorldPoint; its sides are two times the PixelTolerance. All objects that intersect or lie completely within this square are included in the output IGTDDCKeyObjects collection.

The maximum number of objects the IGTDDCKeyObjects collection can contain. Setting this property to a negative number means there is no limit to the number of objects this collection can contain. If a limit is specified and more than the specified number of elements are found, the topmost MaxCandidates elements are returned. Topmost means the elements that are drawn last and so are on top of the other elements.
Defines the use of PickQuick during the locate.
member.remarks:
This method returns an empty collection if no items are located.
The following criteria must be met for a feature to be located by IGTLocateService:
The feature or component must be on the Legend for the map window.
If the display status for the feature is not Display by Scale, then the display status must be On.
If the display status for the feature is Display by Scale, then the current display scale of the map window must be within the display scale range.
The locate status for the feature must be On.
For areas, either the area boundary or the interior of the area (the "face") must intersect the locate tolerance.
The maximum number of items that can be returned by Locate is governed by MaxCandidates parameter of the Locate method.
Features will not be located in these circumstances:
The feature is in database but not on the Legend for the map window.
The feature is on the Legend but display status is Off.
The feature is on the Legend but locate status is Off.
The feature is on the Legend, locate status is On, display status is Off.
The feature is on the Legend but the map window's display scale is outside of the display scale range for the feature (if the feature is Display by Scale).
The number of items that could be found exceeds the MaxCandidates parameter.
Use this method to locate objects in the map window from which the IGTLocateService object was obtained. Locate returns candidates based on what the user can currently see and based what is locatable as indicated in the Display Control. While there may be more data where the mouse is (the input world point), it will not be located unless it can be seen. Therefore, this method is primarily used in commands that use the current mouse position as the input criteria.
If you want data returned that is not visible or locatable in the active map window, use the GTSpatialService instead.
member.returns: Set of IGTDDCKeyObjects given a geographic point.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTLocateService.PickQuick(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTDDCKeyObjects,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPickQuickTypeConstants)
member.summary: Method to select one or more IGTDDCKeyObjects in a collection.
member.param: The items to be displayed in the PickQuick dialog box. If the IGTDDCKeyObjects collection is empty, no action is taken.
The selection mode used by PickQuick.
member.remarks:
If no items are selected, this collection has a count of zero.
Use this method to allow users to select a subset of items within a IGTDDCKeyObjects collection.
Example: Call Locate with gtlsstSelectNone, filter the resulting set of objects for certain conditions, and then use the PickQuick method to let the user choose from among the filtered set of located objects.
member.returns: Collection of user selected IGTDDCKeyObject objects.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTLocateService.IncludeSchematicComponents
member.summary: Property to return/set the IncludeSchematicComponents value. This defaults to false. If true, then client will have to deal with schematic components returned.
member.remarks: This property should be set to True if you want to receive schematics while locating and if the PickQuick software needs to handle schematics.

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTLegendEntry
member.summary: Intergraph G/Technology IGTLegendEntry API.
member.remarks: IGTLegendEntry object represents the status and filter for leaf nodes in the Display Control's tree view.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTLegendEntry.Displayable
member.summary: Property to return/set the displayable status for this legend entry.
member.remarks:
This property returns the current status from the Display Control, even if the user changes it after obtaining this object.
When set, the Display Control's user interface is updated immediately.
Call IGTApplication's RefreshWindows method to see changes in the map window or the plot map frame.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTLegendEntry.Locatable
member.summary: Property to return/set the locatable status for this legend entry.
member.remarks:
This property returns the current status from the Display Control, even if the user changes it after obtaining this object.
When set, the Display Control's user interface is updated immediately.
Locate operations (for example, IGTLocateService.Locate and mouse-locate operations) immediately honor the new setting.
Calling IGTApplication's RefreshWindows method has no effect after setting this property.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTLegendEntry.DisplayScaleMode
member.summary:
Property to return/set the display scale mode for this legend entry.
The DisplayScaleMode property applies only to metadata legend entry nodes and to query nodes. If you change this property for any other node type, an error is raised.
member.remarks:
This property returns the current status from the Display Control, even if the user changes it after obtaining this object.
The G3E_DisplayControlDisplayScaleEnabled database role is honored for this property. If the user does not have the proper role, an error is raised. See the Enabling the Display Scale Status Check Box Help topic.
When set, the Display Control's user interface is updated immediately.
Call IGTApplication's RefreshWindows method to see changes in the map window or the plot map frame.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTLegendEntry.Filter
member.summary: Property to return/set the filter clause for this legend entry.
member.remarks:
This property returns the current filter from the Display Control, even if the user changes it after obtaining this object.
This property applies to metadata legend nodes only; it does not apply to ad hoc nodes.
Setting a new filter replaces the existing filter; the new filter is not combined with the existing filter.
The filter should not include the word, WHERE.
See Supported Operators for the list of supported operators.
If the filter is invalid, an error is raised. The syntax might be wrong or a field in the filter might not apply to this legend entry.
If this property is changed for an ad hoc item, an error is raised.
When set, the Display Control's user interface is updated immediately.
Call IGTApplication's RefreshWindows method to see changes in the map window or the plot map frame.

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTCompositePolygonGeometry
member.summary: Intergraph G/Technology IGTCompositePolygonGeometry API.
member.remarks: IGTCompositePolygonGeometry represents a closed polygon formed by a linear combination of polylines and arcs. Conceptually, IGTCompositePolygonGeometry is just a collection of geometries, except that the geometry elements are required to touch end-to-end and the last point of the last element must be coincident with the first point of the first element.

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTCompositePolylineGeometry
member.summary: Intergraph G/Technology IGTCompositePolylineGeometry API.
member.remarks: IGTCompositePolylineGeometry represents a linear combination of polylines and arcs. Conceptually, GTCompositePolylineGeometry is just a collection of geometries, except that the geometry elements are required to touch end-to-end.

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTGeometryCollection
member.summary: Intergraph G/Technology IGTGeometryCollection API.
member.remarks: The IGTGeometryCollection object is a collection of geometry objects. These geometry objects are created apart from the IGTGeometryCollection object and then added to it. They can also be removed from the collection.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTGeometryCollection.GetComponentKeypointIndexOffset(System.Int32)
member.summary: The GetComponentKeypointIndexOffset function returns the offset from which keypoint indexes begin for a specific component in the given geometry object.
member.remarks:
A geometry object which can have component geometries, such as a GeometryCollection object, contains all of the keypoints defined by its components. It is sometimes necessary to find out what the index of a keypoint defined by a certain component is in the scope of the parent geometry.
Example:
A certain GeometryCollection object, P, contains two components C1 and C2. C1 (a PolylineGeometry) has 5 keypoints, and C2 (an ArcGeometry) has 3 keypoints. Therefore, P has a total of 8 keypoints. To find the index of C2s second keypoint within the scope of P, you can use GetComponentKeypointIndexOffset. The keypoint index offset for C2 in this case would be 5 because C1 has 5 keypoints. So C2s second keypoint has an index of 7 ( 2 + 5) with respect to the list of keypoints in P.
member.param: The index of the component. Must be between 0 and Count-1.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTGeometryCollection.GetParent(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTGeometry)
member.summary: The GetParent method takes a descendent geometry of this geometry and returns the immediate parent of the descendent.
member.param: Some descendent of the root geometry object.
member.remarks: The return value may be this geometry, if it is the immediate parent of the given . If the given is not really a descendant of this geometry, an exception is raised.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTGeometryCollection.Clear
member.summary: Removes all items from the collection.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTGeometryCollection.RemoveAt(System.Int32)
member.summary: Removes the item at the indicated index.
member.param: The index number for the object to be removed. The index must be an integer type.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTGeometryCollection.Count
member.summary: Returns the number of elements in the collection.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTGeometryCollection.IsReadOnly
member.summary: GTGeometryCollection objects are never read-only, so this property always returns false.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTCompositePolylineGeometry.ReplaceVertexByFillet(System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Replaces the vertex specified by the key point index argument on the linear or area geometry by a fillet with the specified radius.
member.remarks:
For CompositePolyline geometries, keypoint_index must specify an interior vertex.
For CompositePolygon geometries, keypoint_index may specify any vertex.
The vertex is replaced by a fillet only if there is a line segment between (keypoint_index - 1) and keypoint_index vertices and there is a line segment between keypoint_index and (keypoint_index + 1) vertices.
The vertex is replaced by a fillet only if the line segments adjacent to the specified vertex are modified. The fillet is not inserted if one or both of the adjacent line segments would be completely eliminated.
Valid case
There is a smooth transition between the fillet arc and the line segments adjacent to the vertex to replace. The vertex will be replaced.
Invalid case
The radius is too large. A complete line segment would be eliminated and there would not be a smooth transition between the fillet arc and the adjacent line segment. The vertex will not be replaced.
Boundary geometry is not valid as the Geometry parameter. If a vertex of a boundary geometry has to be replaced by a fillet, custom code has to retrieve the boundary exterior or a hole where the vertex replacement should take place and pass this subgeometry the Geometry parameter.
If KeyPointIndex specifies an interior vertex of a polyline item, the polyline item is broken into two new polyline items and the fillet arc is inserted between them.
If KeyPointIndex specifies a boundary vertex between two polyline items, the fillet arc is inserted between them. The last vertex of the before item is adjusted to become connected to the start point of the fillet arc. The first vertex of the after item is adjusted to become connected to the end point of the fillet arc.
If KeyPointIndex specifies the first vertex of the composite polygon geometry, the fillet arc is inserted as the first item and the last vertex is adjusted appropriately so that the shape remains closed. The start point of the fillet arc thus becomes the first keypoint of the composite polygon.
If KeyPointIndex specifies the last vertex of the composite polygon geometry, the fillet arc is inserted as the last item, and the first vertex is adjusted appropriately so that the shape remains closed. The end point of the fillet arc thus becomes the last keypoint of the composite polygon.
Example: Input Geometry is a composite polygon consisting of one polyline item.
KeyPointIndex = 1
The fillet arc is the first item of the composite polygon. The polyline is the second item. The last point of the polyline has been adjusted so that it is identical with the start point of the arc.
KeyPointIndex = 5
The polyline is the first item of the composite polygon. Fillet arc is the second item. The first item of the polyline is adjusted so that it is identical with the start point of the fillet arc.
Positional tolerance must be greater than zero for all calculations to complete successfully.
member.param: The key point index of the vertex to be replaced.
The radius of the fillet arc.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTCompositePolygonGeometry.Contains(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPoint)
member.summary: The Contains function determines whether a point is inside this polygon. The polygon is stroked to create a simple polygon.
member.remarks: Returns gtiptOutside if the point is outside the polygon, gtiptOnPolygon if on the polygon, and gtiptInside if it is in the polygon.
member.param: IGTPoint used to determined whether it is inside or outside of the polygon.
member.returns: Result of testing whether a point is inside a polygon.

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTRelationshipService
member.summary: Intergraph G/Technology IGTRelationshipService API.
member.remarks:
The IGTRelationshipService object is used in the editing and review of feature relationships for relationship instances derived from the following types:
Node-Edge Connectivity
Node-Ordered Connectivity
Ownership
Many-to-Many Ownership
Details
Dimensioning
Stationing
This object could be used by a custom command to edit or review a feature's relationships.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTRelationshipService.SilentEstablish(System.Int16,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTKeyObject)
member.summary: Method to silently establish relationships.
member.param: The relationship instance number for the relationship being established.
The IGTKeyObject of the feature that is being related.
member.remarks: Default value gtrelRelationshipOrdinal1 is used for ActiveFeatureRelationshipOrdinal and EstablishToFeatureRelationshipOrdinal.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTRelationshipService.SilentEstablish(System.Int16,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTKeyObject,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTRelationshipOrdinalConstants)
member.summary: Method to silently establish relationships.
member.param: The relationship instance number for the relationship being established.
The IGTKeyObject of the feature that is being related.

If the type of relationship described in the RNO parameter is one that requires relationship point information (NEC, OWN), then this is the integer description of the point on which the active feature will be related to the RelateTo feature.
Example: If the ActiveFeature is a conductor and the RelateTo feature is to be connected at Node 2, this parameter would be set to 2.
member.remarks:
Default value gtrelRelationshipOrdinal1 is used for EstablishToFeatureRelationshipOrdinal.
You cannot use this method to silently establish a relationship with a nongraphic feature.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTRelationshipService.SilentEstablish(System.Int16,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTKeyObject,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTRelationshipOrdinalConstants,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTRelationshipOrdinalConstants)
member.summary: Method to silently establish relationships.
member.param: The relationship instance number for the relationship being established.
The IGTKeyObject of the feature that is being related.

If the type of relationship described in the RNO parameter is one that requires relationship point information (NEC, OWN), then this is the integer description of the point on which the active feature will be related to the RelateTo feature.
Example: If the ActiveFeature is a conductor and the RelateTo feature is to be connected at Node 2, this parameter would be set to 2.

If the type of relationship described in the RNO parameter is one that requires relationship point information (NEC, OWN), then this is the integer description of the point on which the active feature will be related to the RelateTo feature.
member.remarks:
The SilentEstablish method is used when:
The relationship instance to be used is known.
The exact pair of features to be related is known.
The exact relationship point information is known (if applicable for the relationship type given in the RNO parameter).
The two features are given as well as the relationship instance to use in relating the two. If this is a relationship instance that is concerned with relationship point information (NEC and OWN), then these parameters should be set with the correct node or owner ordinal to use for the Active or EstablishTo feature. An error is returned if the constant gtrelRelationshipOrdinalAll is used with either of these parameters.
Generally, AllowSilentEstablish should be called to ensure that there are not any relational attribute conflicts between the ActiveFeature and EstablishToFeature.
You cannot use this method to silently establish a relationship with a nongraphic feature.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTRelationshipService.AllowDelete(System.Int16)
member.summary: Method to verify if relationships may be deleted.
member.param: The relationship instance number for the relationship being established.
member.remarks:
You call the AllowDelete method to determine if there is some reason the relationships of the ActiveFeature should not be deleted. This method can be called before SilentDelete.
The CNO and CID properties of the ActiveFeature must be set to reflect the triggering component instance for which relationships will be deleted.
If any relationship instance has a problem with the delete, then False is returned.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTRelationshipService.SilentDelete(System.Int16)
member.summary: Method to silently delete relationships.
member.param: The relationship instance number for the relationships being deleted.
member.remarks: Default value gtrelRelationshipOrdinalAll is used for RelationshipOrdinal.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTRelationshipService.SilentDelete(System.Int16,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTRelationshipOrdinalConstants)
member.summary: Method to silently delete relationships.
member.param: The relationship instance number for the relationships being deleted.
The relationship ordinal. Node number or Owner ID number, for example, at which relationships should be deleted. If omitted, all relationships will be deleted.
member.remarks:
This method can be used to delete relationships for the relationship instance given in the RNO parameter.
The CNO and CID properties of the ActiveFeature must be set to reflect the triggering component instance for which relationships will be deleted.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTRelationshipService.Reestablish(System.Int16,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTMapWindow)
member.summary: Method to reestablish relationships.
member.param: The relationship instance number for the relationships being reestablished.
The MapWindow in which the active feature resides.
member.remarks: Default value null is used for PreviousTriggeringGeometry.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTRelationshipService.Reestablish(System.Int16,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTMapWindow,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTGeometry)
member.summary: Method to reestablish relationships.
member.param: The relationship instance number for the relationships being reestablished.
The MapWindow in which the active feature resides.
The geometry object of the triggering component of the ActiveFeature.
member.remarks:
Reestablish should be used when a complete reevaluation of relationships to the ActiveFeature is necessary, such as when a feature is moved.
ReestablishAll takes the current state of the feature's relationships and recalculates relationship candidates. Relationships are recomputed based on the latest state of the ActiveFeature. Existing relationships may be lost or maintained based on tolerance and other relationship parameters.
If the triggering geometry of the ActiveFeature was modified, the previous geometry should be provided, if possible. By providing the geometry in its prior state, the software may be able to act more efficiently.
The CNO and CID properties of the ActiveFeature must be set to reflect the triggering component instance of the ActiveFeature for which relationships are being reestablished.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTRelationshipService.ReestablishWithCandidatePoint(System.Int16,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTMapWindow,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPoint)
member.summary: Method to reestablish relationships by providing a point for candidate gathering.
member.param: The relationship instance number for the relationships to be reestablished.
The MapWindow in which the active feature resides.
The point at which relationship candidates should be gathered.
member.remarks: To resolve any candidate or relational ambiguities, the ReestablishWithCandidatePoint method can present GUI to the user.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTRelationshipService.AllowSilentEstablish(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTKeyObject)
member.summary: Method to verify if relationships may be established.
member.param: The IGTKeyObject of the candidate feature. The KeyObject must have been obtained by a call to NewFeature or OpenFeature.
member.remarks:
This method is to be called before SilentEstablish to ensure that there are no relational attribute conflicts.
Example: Call this routine to determine if there is a problem connecting two different cable types such as fiber to copper.
This method returns False if an attribute conflict is found.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTRelationshipService.GetRelatedFeatures(System.Int16)
member.summary: Method to get features related to the ActiveFeature.
member.param: The relationship instance number for which relationships are to be interrogated.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTRelationshipService.GetRelatedFeatures(System.Int16,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTRelationshipOrdinalConstants)
member.summary: Method to get features related to the ActiveFeature.
member.param: The relationship instance number for which relationships are to be interrogated.

The relationship ordinal for which related features are to be retrieved.
Example: If only those features at a given node value are desired, this parameter would be used to define that node1 or 2, for example.
member.remarks:
This method finds all features related to the ActiveFeature and returns them in a IGTKeyObjects collection.
The user canbut is not required toset the CNO and CID properties of the ActiveFeature when reviewing detail or dimensioning relationships. CNO and CID are not needed for other relationships. This is useful when trying to find, for instance, which referencing feature references the detail window in which a particular cable component resides.
Note that the IGTKeyObjects returned have been opened and may be used immediately in edit operations.
