member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTDisplayService.GetDisplayPersistence(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Method to return the DisplayPersistence data associated with a particular Display Control node.
member.param: The names of the nodes of the Display Control hierarchically above the nodes being queried. The path begins with the highest Display Control node and ends with the schematic's node's parent. Each node name in this path is separated by a tab character.
The name of the Display Control node at the top schematic level.
member.remarks: This method can be called only on Schematic nodes. If called for a non-schematic or on a non-existent node, an error will be raised. If called on a node for which SetDisplayPersistence has not been called, it will return the default of gtdspSaveOff.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTDisplayService.SetDisplayPersistence(System.String,System.String,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTDisplayPersistenceConstants)
member.summary: Method to set the DisplayPersistence data associated with a particular Display Control node.
member.param: The names of the nodes of the Display Control hierarchically above the nodes being queried. The path begins with the highest Display Control node and ends with the schematic's node's parent. Each node name in this path is separated by a tab character.
The name of the Display Control node at the top schematic level.
Sets the value of the DisplayPersistence for a schematic existing on the legend.
member.remarks: If called on a non-existent node or for a non-schematic node, an error will be raised.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTDisplayService.GetUserInformation(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Method to return the UserInformation data associated with a particular Display Control node.
member.param: The names of the nodes of the Display Control hierarchically above the nodes being queried. The path begins with the highest Display Control node and ends with the node's parent. Each node name in this path is separated by a tab character.
The name of the Display Control node at the top level.
member.remarks:
This method returns the string that was passed in to SetUserInformation.
This method can be called on any node. If called on a non-existent node, an error will be raised. If called on a node for which SetUserInformation has not been called, it will return the default of an empty string.
The DisplayPathName parameter in this method applies to ad hoc legend entries only, not metadata-defined legend entries. It is used to identify the user interface location of items added by the user or by these methods:
AppendFileByCoordSystem
AppendFile
AppendQuery
AppendRedlines
AppendSchematic
AppendTemporaryGeometries

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTDisplayService.AppendFile(System.String,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTFileTypeConstants)
member.summary: Method to append a file (raster, MicroStation, AutoCAD) to the map associated with this service. The file is not positioned relative to the earth.
member.param: Must be a fully-qualified file. UNC syntax is supported.
File type: raster, AutoCAD, or MicroStation.
member.remarks:
The AppendFile method attaches (at world coordinate X,Y of 0,0) the input file to the map window or map frame from which this service is obtained. The file is not georeferenced, and no transformation is performed.
This method can be used to support interactive registration in a temporary window. Or, it can be used to display non-georeferenced CAD drawings or operation manuals in non-legend-based windows.
An error is raised if the input file is already attached or if the input file has a DDC extension. Use the AppendFileByCoordSystem method for DDC raster files.
AppendFile does not use a display matrix to position the file at a particular georeferenced point. It simply displays a filefor registration purposes, for example. Use AppendFileByCoordSystem if you want the item georeferenced.
The user interface is defaulted as follows:
DisplayMode is on (True).
LocateMode is off (False).
DisplayPosition is gtdsfpBack.
If the FileType is gtfsRaster, the image is located under the Images node (a localized string resource).
If the FileType is gtfsftAutoCAD or gtfsftMicroStation, the CAD file is located under the CAD backdrop data node (a localized string resource).
Files appended with this method are automatically saved in the workspace when the user saves the workspace.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTDisplayService.AppendFileByCoordSystem(System.String,System.String,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTFileTypeConstants)
member.summary: Method to append a file (raster, MicroStation, AutoCAD) to the map associated with this service. The file is positioned using the supplied CoordSystemFile or a coordinate system embedded in the input file.
member.param: Must be a fully-qualified file. UNC syntax is supported.
File type: raster, AutoCAD, or MicroStation.
The location at which this item appears in the Display Control user interface. It is a list of node names, from the top-level to the lowest-level node.
member.remarks:
Default values string.Empty, true, false and gtdsdpBack are used for CoordSystemFile, DisplayMode, LocateMode and DisplayPosition.
An error is raised if the input file is already attached at the input DisplayPathName location.
If the input file has a DDC extension, the input file type is assumed to be gtdsftRaster. The CoordSystemFile is ignored in this case.
If the input file has a DDC extension, the input file type is assumed to be gtdsftRaster. The CoordSystemFile is ignored in this case.
The CoordSystemFile parameter is required in these cases:
When FileType is gtdsftMicroStation.
When FileType is gtdsftAutoCAD.
When FileType is gtdsftRaster and the input file is an Intergraph file without a geo-tie packet.
When FileType is gtdsftRaster and the input file is a world file without a GeoTIFF tag.
The CoordSystemFile parameter is optional in these cases:
When FileType is gtdsftRaster and the input file is an Intergraph file with a geo-tie packet.
When FileType is gtdsftRaster and the input file contains a GeoTIFF tag.
In either case, if the CoordSystemFile is omitted, coordinate system information is retrieved from the file header. Otherwise, the CoordSystemFile is used.
An error is raised if the file is not an Intergraph type, a GeoTIFF, or a World file, such as a TIFF image without a matrix; the AppendFile method can be used in this case.
Files appended with this method are automatically saved in the workspace when the user saves the workspace.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTDisplayService.GetLegendKeys
member.summary: Method to return the legend key(s) for the one or more top-level metadata legend nodes that appear in the Display Control. Top-level metadata legend nodes typically show the configuration name followed by a period followed by the legend's user name.
member.remarks:
There is typically one item in the returned array. However, for each string in the returned array, you can call GetLegendDisplayControlNodes to get its top-level metadata legend node. The DisplayName from each top-level metadata legend node can be presented to the user to choose a legend name.
The returned array of strings is 0-based.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTDisplayService.GetLegendDisplayControlNodes(System.String)
member.summary: Method to return a collection of IGTDisplayControlNode objects.
member.param: Legend key.
member.remarks:
LegendKey must match one of the keys returned from the GetLegendKeys method.
This method returns the top-level metadata legend IGTDisplayControlNode.
This method returns a collection because display groups and legend entries can appear multiple places in the tree view. If multiple nodes are returned, the item appears multiple places in the tree view. The IGTDisplayControlNode's DisplayPathName property can be used to find the particular node of interest.
If the input parameter, LegendKey, does not identify a metadata legend node, an error is raised.
Default value string.Empty is used for LegendItem.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTDisplayService.GetLegendDisplayControlNodes(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Method to return a collection of IGTDisplayControlNode objects.
member.param: Legend key.
Legend item.
member.remarks:
LegendKey must match one of the keys returned from the GetLegendKeys method.
LegendItem must match a specific G3E_LEGENDITEM value in the appropriate G3E_DISPLAYCONTROLTABLE table.
This method returns a collection because display groups and legend entries can appear multiple places in the tree view. If multiple nodes are returned, the item appears multiple places in the tree view. The GTDisplayControlNode's DisplayPathName property can be used to find the particular node of interest.
If LegendItem is a legend entry and multiple are returned, you should only set the properties on one IGTDisplayControlNode.LegendEntry, not all; setting one LegendEntry's properties affects the other LegendEntry objects with the same LegendItem name.
If the input parameters, LegendKey and LegendItem, do not identify a metadata legend node, an error is raised.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTDisplayService.GetAdHocDisplayControlNode(System.String)
member.summary: Method to return the IGTDisplayControlNode.
member.param: DisplayPathName is a tab-delimited string of each parent level in the tree view.

remarks.para: DisplayName is the string representing the lowest level ad hoc node.
The IGTDisplayControlNode represented by DisplayPathName is returned.
The top-level ad hoc items are localized.
For the top-level ad hoc node, the DisplayName is the same as the given DisplayPathName.
If the input parameter, DisplayPathName, does not identify an ad hoc node, an error is raised.

The following is the list of ad hoc node types:
Query
Image
Trace
Temporary Geometry
Schematic
CAD File (DWG, DGN, DDC)
Default value string.Empty is used for DisplayName.

member.returns: The IGTDisplayControlNode represented by DisplayPathName is returned.

DisplayPathName is a tab-delimited string of each parent level in the tree view.

remarks.para: The IGTDisplayControlNode represented by the combination of DisplayPathName and DisplayName is returned.
The top-level ad hoc items are localized.
For the top-level ad hoc node, the DisplayName is the same as the given DisplayPathName.
If the input parameters, DisplayPathName and DisplayName, do not identify an ad hoc node, an error is raised.

The following is the list of ad hoc node types:
Query
Image
Trace
Temporary Geometry
Schematic
CAD File (DWG, DGN, DDC)

member.returns: The IGTDisplayControlNode represented by the combination of DisplayPathName and DisplayName is returned.

The method returns all nodes in the treeview.
The returned collection is static. It is not kept up to date with what a user may add to or remove from the Display Control.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTDisplayService.HiddenComponents
member.summary: Property to return/set the array of hidden components. Each row of the array must define a component to hide by specifying its FNO, FID, CNO and CID.
member.remarks:
The HiddenComponents property returns an object containing a two-dimensional array of components that are currently hidden. If no components are hidden, it returns an empty object.
When set, the HiddenComponents property accepts one of the following:
An empty object.
An array. The array is expected to have four columns containing (in this order) G3E_FNO, G3E_FID, G3E_CNO, and G3E_CID. Each row represents one component to be hidden.
A recordset containing at least the four G3E key fields: G3E_FNO, G3E_FID, G3E_CNO, and G3E_CID. Each row represents one component to be hidden.
IGTDDCKeyObjects collection. Each item in the collection represents one component to be hidden.
If an empty object has been specified, or if the collection does not have any items, or if the recordset does not have any rows, all currently hidden components will no longer be hidden.
Any currently hidden components that are not present in the array/recordset/collection when set will no longer be hidden.
To hide an entire feature, specify all graphical components of the feature, one per row in this array.
If the input variant is not one of the items specified above, or if the array does not have four numeric columns, an error is raised.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTDisplayService.PaperScale
member.summary: Property to return/set the PaperScale on a map window or map frame.
member.remarks:
The paper scale of a map affects the translation of style units to ground units. In the case of schematics, the PaperScale of the map in which a schematic is displayed should match the PaperScale value that was specified to GTSchematicDisplayService when the schematic was created.
Unless it is equal to the constant gtpsWorkspacePaperScale (-1), the specified scale must be a positive integer value. If PaperScale is set to gtpsWorkspacePaperScale, then the paper scale for that map is the default paper scale set in the workspace, which is determined by the Set Paper Space command.
The PaperScale property never returns a value of gtpsWorkspacePaperScale. It always returns the paper scale that is currently in effect for the associated map.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTDisplayService.SelectedDisplayControlNode
member.summary: Property to return the Display Control's selected node.
member.remarks: If no node is currently selected in the Display Control's tree view, null is returned.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPlotWindow.InsertObjectFromFile(System.String,System.Boolean,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPoint)
member.summary: Method to, given a filename, insert an OLE object into the plot.
member.param: The name of the file from which to create the embedded or linked object.
Embedded if False. Linked if True. Defaults to False.
The location of the top-left corner of the new frame.
member.remarks: Default value null is used for BottomRight.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPlotWindow.InsertObjectFromFile(System.String,System.Boolean,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPoint,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPoint)
member.summary: Method to, given a filename, insert an OLE object into the plot.
member.param: The name of the file from which to create the embedded or linked object.
Embedded if False. Linked if True. Defaults to False.
The location of the top-left corner of the new frame.
The bottom-right corner of the new frame.
member.remarks:
The extents of the frame are derived from the extents of the OLE object.
The normal usage should be to leave off the BottomRight argument. This causes the resulting frame to be sized according to the inserted object's natural extents.
If BottomRight is specified, it determines the extents for the frame. This may result in the inserted object's being scaled to fit the specified rectangle.
After calling this method, you must call the GTApplication.RefreshWindows method to make sure the object is redrawn properly.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPlotWindow.InsertObjectFromProgID(System.String,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPoint)
member.summary: Method to, given a ProgID, insert an OLE object into the plot.
member.param: The ProgID with which to create the embedded object.
The location of the top-left corner of the new frame.
member.remarks: Default value null is used for BottomRight.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPlotWindow.InsertObjectFromProgID(System.String,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPoint,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPoint)
member.summary: Method to, given a ProgID, insert an OLE object into the plot.
member.param: The ProgID with which to create the embedded object.
The location of the top-left corner of the new frame.
The bottom-right corner of the new frame.
member.remarks:
The extents of the frame are derived from the extents of the OLE object.
The normal usage should be to leave off the BottomRight argument. This causes the resulting frame to be sized according to the inserted object's natural extents.
If BottomRight is specified, it determines the extents for the frame. This may result in the inserted object's being scaled to fit the specified rectangle.
One use of this method might be to create a new Excel spreadsheet. The GTPlotFrame.EmbeddedObect property can be used to retrieve a pointer to traverse the spreadsheet's automation. With this, the spreadsheet can be populated with data from a map or a query.
After calling this method, you must call the GTApplication.RefreshWindows method to make sure the object is redrawn properly.

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTSegment
member.summary: Intergraph G/Technology IGTSegment API.
member.remarks: IGTSegment represents a line or line segment formed by 2 points. If the segment is "extended", then the line segment is extended infinitely in both directions. Otherwise, the segment is just the line segment between the two points.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTSegment.ProjectPoint(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPoint)
member.summary: The ProjectPoint function projects a given point on to this line segment.
member.param: Input point.
member.remarks: The return is the perpendicular projection of the point onto the segment. If the projection is not on the segment, and the segment's IsExtended property is false, then the point returned is the nearest end point (with Type property equal to GTSegmentPointType.gtsptOnEndpoint). If the projection is not on the segment, and the segment's IsExtended property is true, then the point returned is the perpendicular projection of the point onto the extended segment (with Type property equal to GTSegmentPointType.gtsptOnExtendedSegment). If the projected point is on the segment, the Type property of the return value will be GTSegmentPointType.gtsptOnSegment.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTSegment.Includes(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPoint)
member.summary: Determines if the given point is on this segment. If the segment's IsExtended property is true, this function raises an exception.
member.param: IGTPoint to be tested to find if it is on the segment.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTSegment.Intersect(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTSegment)
member.summary: Computes the intersection of this segment with the given segment. If no intersection exists, an empty array is returned. If the two segments overlap, a single IGTSegmentPoint is returned with a Type property of gtsptOverlap. If either segment's IsExtended property is true, then that segment is considered to be extended infinitely in both directions for the purposes of computing the intersection.
member.param: IGTSegment given for intersection computation.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTSegment.Intersect(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTArcGeometry)
member.summary: Computes the intersection(s) between this segment and the given arc. If this segment's IsExtended property is true, then the intersections include any intersections with the extension of the segment. The returned array may contain zero, one, or two elements. If any intersections are returned, their Type property will either be gtsptOnSegment or gtsptOnExtendedSegment.
member.param: IGTArcGeometry given for intersection computation.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTSegment.ProjectPointAtAngle(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPoint,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPoint,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns a projected point by deriving the lines that pass through the anchor point at the specified angle increment from the original line segment and then projecting the reference point onto the closest derived line.
member.remarks:
Uses positional tolerance.
The angle increment must be greater than 0 and less than or equal to 180 degrees.
The extendability of the input segment is ignored.
member.param: Point used to define the location of the orthogonal line.
Point to be projected onto the orthognal line.
Angle increment used to derive the lines to which the reference point will be projected. For example, an angle increment of 90 would be used to calculate a point orthogonal to the input line segment.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTSegment.Point1
member.summary: Set or returns Point1

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTSegment.Point2
member.summary: Set or returns Point2

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTSegment.Begin
member.summary: Sets or returns the beginning point of the segment.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTSegment.End
member.summary: Sets or returns the ending point of the segment.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTSegment.IsExtended
member.summary: Gets or sets the indication of whether this line segment is extended infinitely in both directions.

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTMultiSectionCableService
member.summary: Intergraph G/Technology IGTMultiSectionCableService API.
member.remarks: The IGTMultiSectionCableService object is used to return the ordered cable sections and component-length labels of a given cable in a multisection cable model.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTMultiSectionCableService.GetOrderedSections
member.summary: Method to return a recordset containing the ordered sections.
member.remarks:
The recordset returned by this method has the following layout:
Field Type Description
G3E_FNO Integer The input cable feature number.
G3E_FID Long The input cable feature identifier.
G3E_CNO Integer The cable section component number.
G3E_CID Integer The cable section component occurrence.
G3E_DETAILID Long The detail ID of the cable section. The value will be Null for geo sections.
G3E_STARTLOCATION Double The start location of the cable section.
G3E_SECTIONLENGTH Double The length of the cable section.
G3E_GEOMETRICLENGTH Double The geometric length of the cable section.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTMultiSectionCableService.GetOrderedComponentLengthLabels(System.Int16,System.Int16)
member.summary: Method to return a recordset containing the ordered component length labels for a given section.
member.param: Differentiates between the geo and detail component labels because the same CID can exist in both of them.
The section component occurrence that relates to the sequence attribute of the component length labels.
member.remarks:
The recordset returned by this method has the following layout:
Field Type Description
G3E_FNO Integer The input cable feature number.
G3E_FID Long The input cable feature identifier.
G3E_SECTIONCNO Integer The cable section component number.
G3E_SECTIONCID Integer The cable section component occurrence.
G3E_DETAILID Long The detail ID of the cable section. The value will be Null for geo sections.
G3E_COMPLENLABELCNO Integer The component number of the cable component length label associated with a cable section.
G3E_ COMPLENLABELCID Integer The component occurrence of the cable component length label associated with a cable section.
G3E_COMPLENGTH Double The component length associated with the cable component length label.
G3E_DISTANCEFROMSTART Double The geometric distance of the component length label from the start point of the cable section.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTComponent.Geometry
member.summary: Property to return/set the geometry associated with the current row of the component recordset.
member.remarks:
This property returns Nothing if there is no geometry. You must position the Recordset to the correct row before getting or setting this property.
The geometry objects can be any of the G/Technology geometry objects.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTComponent.Name
member.summary: Property to return the name of the component.
member.remarks: The name comes from G3E_COMPONENT.G3E_NAME.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTComponent.Recordset
member.summary: Property to return the recordset associated with this component.
member.remarks:
In an Edit scenario, this property causes a database query to be executed when it is first accessed. In a placement scenario, accessing this property does not cause a database query.
Functional interfaces are executed as certain operations are done on the component's recordset.
Example: When you set a field value or GTComponent.Geometry, SetValue Functional interfaces are executed.
AddNew Functional interfaces are executed for each new row that you add. CNO, CID and database defaults are automatically populated. You are responsible for populating FNO and FID.
When adding a row, you have the option of inheriting attribute values from the most recently placed feature. If you use this capability, these attribute values override any database defaults that have been defined.
To take advantage of this, you must supply the FNO when you add a new row.
You can populate other attribute values in the same AddNew call. See the ADO documentation for passing an array of fields and their corresponding values. Or you can populate other attributes after the AddNew call by simply setting the appropriate field values.
When you delete a row, all Functional interfaces defined for this component are created and the Delete method is called on each one.
Update Functional interfaces are executed when this object's contents are saved to the database.
CancelUpdate Functional interfaces are executed when you call GTComponent.Recordset.CancelUpdate.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTComponent.RecordsetLocal
member.summary: Property to return whether the recordset has been populated on the client's machine yet.
member.remarks: True is returned if the GTComponent.Recordset property has previously been requested; otherwise, False is returned.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTComponent.TableName
member.summary: Property to return the database table name associated with this component.
member.remarks: This is the table that is queried when the Recordset property is requested the first time. The table name comes from G3E_COMPONENT.G3E_TABLE.

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTLoopMakeup
member.summary:
The Intergraph G/Technology IGTLoopMakeup Interface can be used to customize the Loop Makeup command in the following areas:
Report titling>
Feature processing
Post processing
The \GTechnology\Services\MetadataEntries\NETSamples\LoopMakeup directory contains an example .NET implementation.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTLoopMakeup.PostProcess(ADODB.Recordset,System.String@)
member.summary: Method called after a successful loop makeup has been performed.
member.remarks:
This method allows you to output the results of a loop makeup to a post process and embellish the report as you see fit.
Additional analytics can be performed on a loop makeup result to provide feedback about potential issues in a network. The loop-makeup-result recordset is provided to the method so that you can provide a string containing an error or warning message pertinent to the loop. The string will be included in the output recordset and may be displayed in a report.
member.param: The loop makeup output recordset containing the results of the loop.
Returns a string containing failures that will be reported to the user at the bottom of the loop makeup report. Use newline string ("\r\n") as separator string between faliure strings.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTLoopMakeup.ProcessFeature(ADODB.Recordset,ADODB.Recordset,System.String@,System.Double@,System.Double@,System.Double@,System.Double@,System.Double@,System.Double@,System.Double@,System.Double@,System.Double@)
member.summary: Method called when any feature defined in the G3E_LMUFeature metadata table is encountered in the network.
member.remarks:
The Loop Makeup command continues to process all the features it supports, but you can override the default calculations with your own calculations or add new features to Loop Makeup.
As Loop Makeup walks the traced network from the starting point to the ending point, feature by feature, the processor is called. The feature processor can specify the following:
Any change to the total length, total resistance, or total loss.
Any length, resistance, or loss that will be added to the totals and included as part of the output recordset.
Any length, resistance, or loss that will be added to the build out totals and included as part of the output recordset.
Any custom annotation for the feature on the report.
member.param: The recordset of input parameters to the command. See LMUInput Recordset structure below.
The feature recordset currently being processed and on the correct row.
The description to annotate in the output recordset. This is set by the command but may be overwritten by the interface.
Returns the calculated resistance the current feature applies to the total buildout loss.
Returns the calculated resistance the current feature applies to the total buildout resistance.
Returns the calculated resistance the current feature applies to the total buildout length.
Returns the calculated loss the current feature applies to the total network loss. This value is automatically added to the total loss by the loop makeup command.
Returns the calculated resistance the current feature applies to the total network resistance. This value is automatically added to the total resistance by the loop makeup command.
Returns the calculated length the current feature applies to the total network length. This value is automatically added to the total length by the loop makeup command.
The current total accumulated loss which may be reset by the interface.
The current total accumulated resistance which may be reset by the interface.
The current total accumulated length which may be reset by the interface.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTLoopMakeup.ReportTitle(ADODB.Recordset,System.String@)
member.summary: Method called after a successful loop makeup and before the post process has been performed. This method provides a mechanism to override the Loop Makeup report title.
member.remarks: This method could be used, for example, to retrieve the address of the starting feature.
member.param: The loop makeup output recordset containing the results of the loop.
Specifies and returns the title for the loop makeup report.

0 = Geographic

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTSpatialService.GetResultsByFNO(System.Int16[],System.Int16,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTComponentGeometryConstants)
member.summary: Method to return records from the component views (as specified by the input FNOArray and ComponentViewRetrievalMode) whose geometry relates spatially to the FilterGeometry based on the Operator.
member.param: Array of feature numbers.
0 = Geographic
Use the gtddcgPrimaryGeographic constant to indicate Primary Geographic or Alternate Geographic components.
member.remarks: Default value false is used for IncludeReferencingFeatureRecords.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTSpatialService.GetResultsByFNO(System.Int16[],System.Int16,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTComponentGeometryConstants,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Method to return records from the component views (as specified by the input FNOArray and ComponentViewRetrievalMode) whose geometry relates spatially to the FilterGeometry based on the Operator.
member.param: Array of feature numbers.
0 = Geographic
Use the gtddcgPrimaryGeographic constant to indicate Primary Geographic or Alternate Geographic components.
When this argument is set to True, the service looks at the detail referencing features in addition to the features specified in the FNOArray.
member.remarks:
The returned ADODB.Recordset has key fields (G3E_FNO, G3E_FID, G3E_CNO, and G3E_CID).
If the value in G3E_DETAILMAPPING.G3E_CONTAINEDFNO is in the FNOArray, then any features of the feature class specified by G3E_DETAILMAPPING.G3E_REFERENCINGFNO that meet the spatial criteria will be included in the resulting recordset.
Referencing features define detail areas (identified in G3E_DETAIL) that can contain the features specified in the FNOArray argument. There may not actually be any features from the FNOArray in the detail areas. You will have to use the detail identifier associated with these referencing features to issue a query to find the actual instance data for the contained features.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTSpatialService.WriteResultsByComponentView(System.String)
member.summary: Method to write keys to the database for those records from the input component view whose geometry relates spatially to the FilterGeometry based on the Operator.
member.param: Component view whose geometry is to be compared to FilterGeometry.
member.remarks: Default value G3E_TEMPKEYS is used for TemporaryTable.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTSpatialService.WriteResultsByComponentView(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Method to write keys to the database for those records from the input component view whose geometry relates spatially to the FilterGeometry based on the Operator.
member.param: Component view whose geometry is to be compared to FilterGeometry.
Default value is G3E_TEMPKEYS.
member.remarks:
A database transaction must be started before this method is called. The caller is also expected to commit the transaction after calling this method.
The method writes key field (G3E_FNO, G3E_FID, G3E_CNO, and G3E_CID) values to the specified temporary database table. The method does not create the specified temporary table in the database. The temporary table must already exist with key fields.
If callers do not start a transaction or do not specify a temporary table, then they must maintain the table and identify the written records by the method.

member.summary: Method to write keys to the database for those records from the component views (as specified by the input FNOArray and ComponentViewRetrievalMode) whose geometry relates spatially to the FilterGeometry based on the Operator.

member.remarks:
A database transaction must be started before this method is called. The caller is also expected to commit the transaction after calling this method.
The method writes key field (G3E_FNO, G3E_FID, G3E_CNO, and G3E_CID) values to the specified temporary database table. The method does not create the specified temporary table in the database. The temporary table must already exist with key fields.

Referencing features define detail areas (identified in G3E_DETAIL) that can contain the features specified in the FNOArray argument. There may not actually be any features from the FNOArray in the detail areas. You will have to use the detail identifier associated with these referencing features to issue a query to find the actual instance data for the contained features.
If callers do not start a transaction or do not specify a temporary table, then they must maintain the table and identify the written records by the method.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTSpatialService.FilterGeometry
member.summary: Property to return/set the geometry used to filter component view records.
member.remarks:
Specifying the FilterGeometry property is required.
The following are the valid filter-geometry types (GTGeometryCollection is not supported):
IGTArcGeometry
IGTBoundaryGeometry
IGTCompositePolygonGeometry
IGTCompositePolylineGeometry
IGTLineGeometry
IGTOrientedPointGeometry
IGTPointGeometry
IGTPolygonGeometry
IGTPolylineGeometry
IGTTextPointGeometry(the text origin will be used for spatial processing and not the MBR of the text)

member.remarks: Specifying the Operator property is required.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTExportService.PDFLayersEnabled
member.summary: Property to return/set whether PDF layers should be exported. Default value is true.
member.remarks:
Applies to the SaveAsPDF methods only.
When set to false, PDF layers are not exported.
When set to true, PDF layer processing is enabled. This means PDF layers have the potential to be exported. However, there are restrictions that can keep them from being exported:
If there are any translucent items in the window, layers are not exported.

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTSchematicLabel
member.summary: Intergraph G/Technology IGTSchematicLabel API. Represents the label of a schematic element.
member.remarks:
Represents the label of a schematic element. Each IGTSchematicLabel object represents a label for a schematic element. This object allows IGTAugmentNetworkAttribution to specify the characteristics of the label or to modify the component view data used to generate the label.
When Generate is called on the parent IGTSchematicElement, or when the IGTAugmentNetworkAttribution object returns from its Execute method, the first element in the Primary property's collection is used to generate the label. If the Primary property's collection is empty, the first element of the A lternate property's collection is used. If that collection is also empty, then no label will be generated for this IGTSchematicLabel object.
The Position and Alignment properties together specify where the label text is drawn. Each label has a geographic location, a point, that tells the display system where the label is located. The Position property specifies to GTSchematicDisplayService how to calculate that point's location, relative to the element (a node or an edge) it is labeling.
The Alignment property further tells the display system where to draw the label text relative to the point computed from the Position.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTSchematicLabel.Alignment
member.summary: Gets of sets the horizontal alignment of a label.
member.remarks: The alignment of a label specifies how the text is drawn in relation to the label's geometric location. An Alignment of gtalCenterCenter draws the text so that the center (both horizontally and vertically) of the label text aligns with the geographic position of the label. An Alignment of gtalTopLeft draws the label so that the top-left corner of the label text aligns with the geographic position of the label. This is the same as the alignment specification for a text style in the G/Technology display system.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTSchematicLabel.Alternate
member.summary: Gets the alternate component view data instances of an element.
member.remarks: There is one item in this collection for each row found in the alternate component view whose G3E_FID matches the G3E_FID in the element. If there are no matching records, or if an alternate view is not specified in the metadata, the collection is empty.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTSchematicLabel.Index
member.summary: Gets the zero-based index of a label within the IGTSchematicElement.GTSchematicLabels collection.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTSchematicLabel.Position
member.summary: Gets or sets the vertical position of a label.
member.remarks: The position of a label specifies its geographic location relative to the element it labels.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTSchematicLabel.Primary
member.summary: Gets the primary component view data instances.
member.remarks: There is one item in this collection for each row found in the primary component view whose G3E_FID matches the G3E_FID in the element. If there are no matching records, the collection is empty.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTSchematicLabel.StyleID
member.summary: Gets or sets the style identifier of a label.
member.remarks: This property is Null until the IGTSchematicElement.Generate method has been called.

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPrintProperties
member.summary: Intergraph G/Technology IGTPrintProperties API.
member.remarks:
The IGTPrintProperties object is used in the IGTPlotWindow.PrintPlot method to specify information about the output. These properties, if specified, override any printer settings specified through Page Setup or the printer's Properties page. In all cases, if one of these properties is not set, the default is determined by Page Setup or by the printer's properties.
There are several ways to specify what size paper to use for printing. In order of increasing precedence, they are as follows:
Set the PaperSize property to a valid standard paper size designation.
Set the PaperName property to a valid standard paper size name.
Set the PaperWidth and PaperHeight properties to the desired dimensions.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPrintProperties.Copies
member.summary: Property to return/set the number of copies to print.
member.remarks: If not set, this value defaults to 1.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPrintProperties.DocumentName
member.summary: Property to return/set the name given to the print job.
member.remarks: Typically, this name appears in the printer's queue listing to indicate the document being printed. It is also used by some PDF and other file format printer drivers as a default for the file name.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPrintProperties.Orientation
member.summary: Property to return/set the print layout(Portrait/Landscape).
member.remarks:
Paper size is always specified as width times height, where width is always less than height.
Using a gtpoPortrait orientation causes the output to appear on the page with the width horizontal and height vertical. Using gtpoLandscape causes the output to appear on the page with the width vertical and height horizontal.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPrintProperties.PaperHeight
member.summary: Property to return/set a custom height for the paper.
member.remarks: If this property is set, then the PaperWidth property must also be set, and together they override any setting of PaperName or PaperSize. This value is specified in paper units.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPrintProperties.PaperName
member.summary: Property to return/set the paper size using a name from a set of enumerated values.
member.remarks: This property overrides any settings of PaperSize, but is ignored if both PaperWidth and PaperHeight are set.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPrintProperties.PaperSize
member.summary: Property to return/set the paper size using a set of enumerated values.
member.remarks: This property is ignored if the PaperName property is set or if both the PaperWidth and PaperHeight properties are set.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPrintProperties.PaperWidth
member.summary: Property to return/set a custom width for the paper.
member.remarks: If this property is set, then the PaperHeight property must also be set, and together they override any setting of PaperName or PaperSize. This value is specified in paper units.

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTMatrix
member.summary: Intergraph G/Technology IGTMatrix API.
member.remarks:
IGTMatrix represents a 4x4 three-dimensional matrix. IGTMatrix is often used to hold a coordinate transformation matrix. The elements of a transformation matrix have the following meanings:
Element 0,0X-coordinate portion of scaling/rotation of X
Element 0,1X-coordinate portion of scaling/rotation of Y
Element 0,2X-coordinate portion of scaling/rotation of Z
Element 0,3Translation of X-coordinate.
Element 1,0Y-coordinate portion of scaling/rotation of X
Element 1,1Y-coordinate portion of scaling/rotation of Y
Element 1,2Y-coordinate portion of scaling/rotation of Z
Element 1,3Translation of Y-coordinate.
Element 2,0Z-coordinate portion of scaling/rotation of X
Element 2,1Z-coordinate portion of scaling/rotation of Y
Element 2,2Z-coordinate portion of scaling/rotation of Z
Element 2,3Translation of Z-coordinate.
Element 3,0Should be 0.0
Element 3,1Should be 0.0
Element 3,2Should be 0.0
Element 3,3Should be 1.0
All other elements should be equal to the corresponding elements of the identity matrix.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTMatrix.Multiply(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTMatrix,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTMatrix)
member.summary: Returns the product of the two given matrices.
member.param: A GTMatrix object.
A GTMatrix object.

member.summary: Returns the inverse of this matrix.

member.param: A IGTVector object.

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTArcGeometry
member.summary: Intergraph G/Technology IGTArcGeometry API.
member.remarks: The IGTArcGeometry object represents a circular arc. Arcs are defined by a starting point, an ending point, a radius, a normal vector, and a "greater than pi" flag. By defining the arc this way, we guarantee that the starting and ending points are exact, which provides accurate "meeting points" with other line and arc geometries in a linear feature.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTArcGeometry.ComputeArcByRadiusAndTangents(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPoint,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPoint,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPoint,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPoint,System.Double)
member.summary:
Returns an arc with the specified . The given tangent points determine two lines that are tangent to the arc at the arc's starting and ending points. Note that the lines are extended in either direction as far as necessary to be tangent to the arc.
If no arc can be determined from the given input values, the ArgumentOutOfRangeException is thrown. For example, if the given lines are parallel, a unique arc is not determinable.
member.remarks:
The start point of the arc is on extended line (Start1, End1) and its end point is on extended line (Start2, End2). The tangent of the arc at its start point is the same as the angle of (Start1, End1). The tangent of the arc at its end point is the same as the angle of (Start2, End2). The arc has the radius specified by the Radius input parameter.
If this method is used to compute a fillet arc, the caller may need to perform additional validation of the input parameters based on what is considered to be a fillet in the workflow being implemented.
If computing a fillet arc, the custom code may also need to validate whether the output arc is a valid fillet in the workflow being implemented.
Positional tolerance must be greater than zero for all calculations to complete successfully.
member.param: Starting point of the first tangent line.
Ending point of the first tangent line.
Starting point of the second tangent line.
Ending point of the second tangent line.
The radius of the cicle containing the arc.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTArcGeometry.ComputeArcByPointAndTangents(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPoint,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPoint,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPoint,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPoint)
member.summary:
This method is similar to ComputeArcByRadiusAndTangents, except that the second given point, , represents the endpoint of the first tangent line and the starting point of the arc.
If no arc can be determined from the given input values, the ArgumentOutOfRangeException is thrown.
member.remarks:
The start point of the arc is identical with End1 and the end point of the arc is on the extended line (Start2, End2). The tangent of arc at its start point is the same as the angle of the line (Start1, End1). The tangent of arc at its end point is the same as the angle of the line (Start2, End2).
When the lines (Start1, End1) and (Start2, End2) are parallel (but not collinear), the end point of the arc is calculated as an intersection of the extended line Start2, End2 and the line perpendicular to (Start1, End1) passing through End1.
If this method is used to compute a fillet arc, the caller may need to perform additional validation of the input parameters based on what is considered to be a fillet in the workflow being implemented.
If computing a fillet arc, the custom code may also need to validate whether the output arc is a valid fillet in the workflow being implemented.
Positional tolerance must be greater than zero for all calculations to complete successfully.
member.param: Starting point of the first tangent line.
Ending point of the first tangent line and starting point of the arc.
Starting point of the second tangent line.
Ending point of the second tangent line.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTArcGeometry.ComputeArcsBy2PointsAndRadius(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPoint,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPoint,System.Double)
member.summary:
Returns an array of IGTArcGeometry objects representing all possible arcs with the given starting point, ending point, and radius. The returned array may have 0, 2, or 4 elements, depending on the relationship between the given radius and the distance between the and points:
Number of arcsCondition
0 Given radius is greater than the distance between and .
2 Given radius is exactly equal to the distance between and . Each arc is a semicircle.
4 Given radius is less than the distance between and . The 4 arcs form two circles that intersect at the given points.
The length of the returned array can be used to determine how many arcs were computed.
member.param: Starting point of the arc.
Ending point of the arc.
Radius of the circle containing the arc.
member.remarks:
The method returns the number of computed arcs as follows:
No arc is returned if 2 * Radius is less than the distance between Start and End.
No arc is also returned if Start and End are within positional tolerance.
Two arcs (half-circles) are returned if 2 * Radius equals the distance between Start and End.
Four arcs are returned if 2 * Radius is greater than the distance between Start and End.
Note: The order in which the four output parameters of this function are populated with arc geometries may differ from the order in which the arcs are indexed on the above picture.
Positional tolerance must be greater than zero for all calculations to complete successfully.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTArcGeometry.ComputeArcBy2PointsAndTangent(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPoint,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTPoint,System.Double)
member.summary:
Returns an arc with the given starting and ending points, where the tangent line to the arc at the starting point forms an angle of radians with the positive x-axis.
Note that ComputeArcBy2PointsAndTangent(p1, p2, angle) and ComputeArcBy2PointsAndTangent(p1, p2, angle+pi) yield complementary arcs that form a complete circle.
If no arc can be determined from the given input values, the ArgumentOutOfRangeException is thrown. For example, if the angle formed by the line through and is equal to , no arc can be computed.
member.remarks: Positional tolerance must be greater than zero for all calculations to complete successfully.
member.param: Starting point of the arc.
Ending point of the arc.
Angle between the arc starting point tangent and positive x-axis.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTArcGeometry.Intersect(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTSegment)
member.summary: Computes the intersection(s) between this arc and the given segment. If the segment's IsExtended property is true, then the intersections include any intersections with the extension of the segment. The returned array may contain zero, one, or two elements. If any intersections are returned, their Type property will either be gtsptOnSegment or gtsptOnExtendedSegment.
member.param: IGTSegment given for intersection computation.
member.returns: An array of Intersection points between the arc and a given segment

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTArcGeometry.Intersect(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTArcGeometry)
member.summary: Computes the intersection(s) between this arc and the given arc. The returned array may contain zero, one, or two elements. If the arcs overlap, then one element will be returned with a Type property of gtsptOverlap. Otherwise, the Type property of all returned elements (if any) will be gtsptOnSegment.
member.param: IGTArcGeometry given for intersection computation.
member.returns: An array of Intersection points between the arc and a given arc

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTArcGeometry.Start
member.summary: Returns or sets the starting point of the arc.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTArcGeometry.End
member.summary: Returns or sets the ending point of the arc.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTArcGeometry.Radius
member.summary: Returns or sets the radius of the arc.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTArcGeometry.Normal
member.summary:
Returns or sets the normal vector for the arc. The normal vector determines the direction of the arc's sweep as well as the plane of the arc. The sweep direction follows the right-hand rule for vectors. For example, a normal of [0, 0, 1] (in the positive Z-direction) determines an arc in the XY-plane that sweeps counter-clockwise.
Given a starting point, and ending point, and a radius, there are an infinite number of possible arcs with those properties. When the arc is restricted to a particular plane by the Normal vector, there are 4 possible arcs -- two that sweep clockwise and two that sweep counter-clockwise. The Normal vector's direction (using the right-hand rule) further narrows these choices to two.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTArcGeometry.GreaterThanPi
member.summary: Returns or sets a Boolean flag determining whether the arc is greater than (true) or less than or equal (false) to a half circle. This flag chooses one of the two possible arcs that pass through the given starting and ending points with the given radius and Normal vector.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTArcGeometry.Origin
member.summary: Returns the center point of this arc. .

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTArcGeometry.MidPoint
member.summary: Returns the midpoint -- the point on the arc halfway between the Start and End points -- of this arc. .

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTTransactionManager
member.summary: Intergraph G/Technology IGTTransactionManager API.
member.remarks:
A IGTTransactionManager object manages database transactions. Its methods and properties are passed as part of a Custom Command interface and Import Feature interface.
IGTTransactionManager is available to a custom command if its enabling conditions include "New transaction available" and if there is an active job when the command is first invoked. This implies that you should also set the "Active job exists" enabling condition.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTTransactionManager.Begin(System.String)
member.summary: Method to begin a transaction.
member.param: Identifies the current transaction. This value will appear in the Undo command menu item after the transaction is committed.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTTransactionManager.Commit
member.summary: Method to end a transaction, save changes to the database and optionally refresh deltas for the active job.
member.remarks: Default value true is used for RefreshJobChanges.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTTransactionManager.Commit(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Method to end a transaction, save changes to the database and optionally refresh deltas for the active job.
member.param: Indicates whether or not job changes should be refreshed.
member.remarks:
Although passing True or omitting the parameter is the most common usage, there are cases where it makes sense to pass False. In each case, the goal is to make the client software and the database do the least amount of work, which yields faster processing.
Examples:
You are doing several transactions in one command. It is correct to pass False for the first transactions and True for the final transaction. Passing True on the final transaction refreshes all job changes made in the earlier transactions as well as the last one.
Your command requires database changes from all users to be seen in the client. You should pass False to Commit for each transaction done by your command. After calling Commit with False on the final transaction, you should call IGTTransactionManager.RefreshDatabaseChanges. This refreshes all database changes made recently by other users, and it refreshes all job changes made in the transactions just committed.
After calling the Commit method, you should call the IGTApplication's RefreshWindows method to display the changes in the application windows. If your command calls Commit multiple times, it is best to call RefreshWindows one time after the final Commit or after calling RefreshDatabaseChanges, whichever is last.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTTransactionManager.Rollback
member.summary: Method to end a transaction without saving changes to the database.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTTransactionManager.RefreshDatabaseChanges
member.summary: Method to refresh the current session with the database changes from all users who have posted master database changes. This broadcast includes all master deltas and deltas for the active job.
member.remarks:
Calling this function causes the contents of the select set to be cleared, removing all objects from the IGTSelectedObjects collection.
This method should be used sparingly. The Commit method topic describes how to refresh changes to the active job only. The Commit method also gives an example as to when you might call Commit followed by RefreshDatabaseChanges. However, these methods are not typically combined.
After calling the RefreshDatabaseChanges method, you should call the IGTApplication.RefreshWindows method to display the changes in the application windows.

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTSchematicGeneratorService
member.summary: Intergraph G/Technology IGTSchematicGeneratorService API.
member.remarks:
The IGTSchematicGeneratorService object provides the interface for specifying the format and other layout parameters of a schematic. It also provides the interface for obtaining the resulting layout merged with the correct symbology and label content.
The IGTSchematicGeneratorService accepts the network data and layout parameters and combines these with metadata to generate a schematic. The service then gathers and measures the symbology information and label content for each feature in the trace data. Optionally, the data can be processed by the IGTAugmentNetworkAttribution object. The IGTSchematicGeneratorService performs the actual layout of the schematic and augments the input data with the location, rotation, and other information about the schematic entities that it positioned during the layout phase. The IGTSchematicGeneratorService can also append and update trace data to existing schematic data. The following diagram displays the functional areas of the schematic generation process that are encapsulated by the service:
The schematic input parameters, network data, resulting layout, and all other information is stored and shared between the components as XML. The structure is defined using an XML schema. The XML will not only preserve the schematic data (final graphic layout), but all the information that was needed to create it.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTSchematicGeneratorService.Append(System.String,ADODB.Recordset)
member.summary: Method to append the specified network of entities with the specified unique identifier to the schematic.
member.param: The name given to the network of entities.
The network of entities to append to the schematic.
member.remarks:
Specifying the Append method will append a new network of entities with the specified name to the schematic and return a unique identifier.
Append Method Input Recordset Definition
This recordset defines a network that is appended using the GTSchematicGeneratorService Append method. The data types are ADODB.DataTypeEnum enumerated values.
Typically, results from the TRACERESULT table will be used to create the input recordset; however, the input recordset could come from customized code that uses the fields as specified in the Recordset Definition table. In this case, connectivity will have to be properly defined. See the Trace Results Table topic for further information.
The following fields are required in the input recordset. These same fields are also used in a query from the TRACERESULT table. The TRACERESULT table is used by the Schematic Manager sample command.
Field Name Optional Null Data Type Description
G3E_FID No No adInteger The feature identifier of the network entity.
G3E_FNO No No adSmallInt The feature number of the network entity.
G3E_TRACEORDER No No adInteger The order in which the network entity was discovered during the trace.
G3E_NODE1 No No adInteger The first node value given to the entity from the relationship table.
G3E_NODE2 No No adInteger The second node value given to the entity from the relationship table.
G3E_SOURCENODE No No adInteger The node value from the relationship table that sourced this network entity.

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTSchematicAttribute
member.summary: Intergraph G/Technology IGTSchematicAttribute API.
member.remarks: IGTSchematicAttribute object represents a field of the component view for a schematic element. Besides giving access to the column name and the value of the field, this object also provides a property, IncludeInXML, that allows the IGTAugmentNetworkAttribution object to specify whether or not the field should be included in the generated XML.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTSchematicAttribute.ColumnName
member.summary: Gets or sets the column name of an attribute.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTSchematicAttribute.IncludeInXML
member.summary: Gets or sets whether to include an attribute in the schematic XML.
member.remarks:
If this property is set to True, this attribute is added to the UserAttributes element of the Node or Edge XML element. UserAttributes contains a child element for each attribute whose IncludeInXML property was True. This child element has a ColumnName and a Value attribute, whose values are the value of the ColumnName and Value properties of this object. The Value property will be converted to a string to populate the Value XML attribute.
The default value of this property is False, indicating that attributes from the component view are not included in the XML by default.

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTOrientedPointGeometry
member.summary: Intergraph G/Technology IGTOrientedPointGeometry API.
member.remarks:
Represents a point geometry with an orientation (i.e., rotation). The IGTOrientedPointGeometry object consists of a single point and an orientation vector. The point is stored as a IGTPoint object in the Origin property. The coordinates for the origin can be returned or modified through the X, Y, and Z properties of the IGTPoint object. The orientation is stored as a IGTVector object in the Orientation property. The components of the orientation vector can be returned or modified through the I, J, and K properties of the IGTVector object.
Typically, the IGTOrientedPointGeometry object is rendered in a map window with a style object that shows orientation such as a SymbolFontStyle or a BitmapStyle object. The orientation vector determines the direction in which the symbol or bitmap for the IGTOrientedPointGeometry object is rendered.
The following illustration shows a point feature symbolized with two different orientation vectors:
Orientation vector = 1,0,0
Orientation vector = 1,1,0

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTOrientedPointGeometry.Orientation
member.summary: Returns or sets the orientation (rotation) of the point. A vector of [1, 0, 0] (the positive x-axis) represents no rotation.

member.summary: Method to create a new feature instance with the appropriate defaults.
member.param: Feature number of the new feature to be created.
If this parameter is True, then attributes are copied from the last placement of a similar featureone whose FNO and ClassificationAttributeValue are the same.
member.remarks: Default value null is used for ClassificationAttributeValue. See the Remarks section for the IGTDataContext.NewFeature(Int16, Boolean, Object) method for more details.
member.returns: The IGTKeyObject of the new feature.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTDataContext.NewFeature(System.Int16,System.Boolean,System.Object)
member.summary: Method to create a new feature instance with the appropriate defaults.
member.param: Feature number of the feature to be created.
Attribute value that further qualifies the input FNO. For example, you might want to differentiate a cable feature by its type: coax, wire, copper.
If this parameter is True, then attributes are copied from the last placement of a similar featureone whose FNO and ClassificationAttributeValue are the same.
member.remarks:
IGTDataContext is responsible for caching the new IGTKeyObject until the transaction is committed or rolled back.
This method fails if no transaction is in progress.
The feature (IGTKeyObject) returned from this method provides important capabilities such as the firing of Functional interfaces and Attribute Edit Control interfaces when edits are made to a component's recordset.
Normally a record is added to each required component's recordset. When a record is added, it is populated with database default values and the G3E_FNO, G3E_FID, G3E_CNO, and G3E_CID key values. However, if the required component also has its G3E_FEATURECOMPONENT.G3E_ALTERNATEREQUIREDCNO field populated, a record is not added. It is up to the caller to add the necessary record in this case.
If the UseLastFeatureAttributes parameter is False no additional work happens. However, if the UseLastFeatureAttributes parameter is True, the new feature has the following additional characteristics:
If the input FNO-ClassificationAttributeValue combination has been previously placed or cached, the new feature's components are populated with additional records so that the number of records in each component matches that of the previous feature. Otherwise, no additional records are created.
Attribute values are populated for each component record created in the previous steps. Attribute values are applied in the following order so that subsequent steps overwrite values, including database defaults, populated in a previous step:
Job classification values are applied.
Attribute values for attributes defined to be copied are copied from components of a previously placed or cached feature having the same FNO-ClassificationAttributeValue combination. The values are copied into the appropriate record by matching the G3E_CNO value.
If the input FNO-ClassificationAttributeValue combination has not been placed or cached previously, this step is skipped.
Note: Dialog attribute values do not get applied by this method.
See the Attribute Inheritance and Preloading topic for more details.
member.returns: The IGTKeyObject of the new feature.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTDataContext.OpenFeature(System.Int16,System.Int32)
member.summary: Method to open a feature for editing or reviewing.
member.remarks:
This method returns an IGTKeyObject even if a transaction is not in progress. If a transaction is not in progress, the returned IGTKeyObject is not cached; it is read-only and any changes to the feature are temporary. If a transaction is in progress, the returned IGTKeyObject is cached until the transaction is committed or rolled back. Any edits to the feature are saved when the transaction is committed.
When caching is enabled (that is, a transaction is in progress), you should not call OpenFeature to open thousands or even hundreds of features at a time. If you must open many features, and you are calling this method in the context of a custom command, consider calling IGTTransactionManager.Commit on sets of 100 or fewer features. If you are calling OpenFeature in the context of another interface (for example, the IGTPostProcess interface), you do not have control of the transaction, and therefore you cannot call IGTTransactionManager.Commit on sets of 100 features. In this case, you should consider alternative means for updating many features. A database procedure is one choice. Converting your IGTPostProcess interface to a custom command is another choice. If you implement a database procedure, you must understand that Functional interfaces and Attribute edit Control interfaces are not executed.
If caching is not enabled (that is, a transaction is not in progress), you should still limit the number of IGTKeyObject objects that are instantiated at any given time, although the number you can open is higher (in the hundreds). However, this still may not be the most efficient means of accessing the data. For read-only access to large quantities of data, especially from multiple component tables, consider using IGTDataContext.OpenRecordset to query the precise data you need. This approach ensures that you get the data in one query to the database, instead of possibly many queries.
For the given FNO, FID, the returned IGTKeyObject object has an IGTComponents collection property that exposes access to each IGTComponent object that makes up the returned feature. Each IGTComponent has a Recordset property that exposes the records, fields, and values for a given component instance (CNO, CID). Calling Recordset.AddNew, Recordset.Delete, or making edits to existing Recordset field values causes IGTFunctional and IGTAttributeEditControl interfaces to execute.
Do not call Recordset.Update. It does not do anything because these Recordsets are disconnected from the underlying database connection. Instead, changes to the IGTComponent's Recordset are saved to the database when you explicitly call GTTransactionManager.Commit from your custom command or when the governing product command commits its transaction. The "Update" IGTFunctional interfaces are executed as part of the commit operation.
You cannot use the same IGTKeyObject in multiple transactions. Depending on the .Net code language that is used, you should set the IGTKeyObject to Nothing(VB.Net) or null(C#) after calling IGTTransactionManager.Commit because it is no longer in the underlying cache. You must call OpenFeature again to make subsequent edits to the same feature.
member.param: Feature number of the feature to be opened.
Feature ID of the feature to be opened.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTDataContext.NewPlacementConfiguration(System.Int32)
member.summary: Method to create new feature instances with the appropriate defaults for each feature in the placement configuration.
member.param: Placement configuration number.
member.remarks: Default values true and null are used for UseLastFeatureAttributes and ClassificationAttributeValue.

DataContext is responsible for caching each new feature's IGTKeyObject until the transaction is committed or rolled back.
This method fails if no transaction is in progress.
The features returned from this method provide important capabilities such as the firing of Functional interfaces and Attribute Edit Control interfaces when edits are made to a component's recordset.
If the UseLastFeatureAttributes parameter is False, each new feature simply has a record (populated with database default values and the G3E_FNO, G3E_FID, G3E_CNO, and G3E_CID key values) inserted into the recordset of each required component.
If the UseLastFeatureAttributes parameter is True (the default value), each new feature has the following characteristics:
A record (initially populated with database default values and the G3E_FNO, G3E_FID, G3E_CNO, and G3E_CID key values) is inserted into the recordset of each required component.
If an input FNO-ClassificationAttributeValue combination has been previously placed or cached, the components of the new feature are populated with additional records so that the number of records in each component matches that of the previous feature. Otherwise, no additional records are created.
For each component record created in the previous step, attribute values are populated in the following order so that subsequent steps overwrite values, including database defaults:
Job classification values are applied.
For attributes defined to be copied, values are copied from components of a previously placed or cached feature having the same FNO-ClassificationAttributeValue combination. The values are copied into the appropriate record by matching the G3E_CNO value. If an input FNO-ClassificationAttributeValue combination has not been placed or cached previously, this step is skipped.
Note:Dialog attribute values do not get applied by this method.
See the Attribute Inheritance and Preloading topic for more details.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTDataContext.NewPlacementConfiguration(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Method to create new feature instances with the appropriate defaults for each feature in the placement configuration.
member.param: Placement configuration number.
Determines if attributes are copied from the last placement of a feature whose FNO and ClassificationAttributeValue are the same.

DataContext is responsible for caching each new feature's IGTKeyObject until the transaction is committed or rolled back.
This method fails if no transaction is in progress.
The features returned from this method provide important capabilities such as the firing of Functional interfaces and Attribute Edit Control interfaces when edits are made to a component's recordset.
If the UseLastFeatureAttributes parameter is False, each new feature simply has a record (populated with database default values and the G3E_FNO, G3E_FID, G3E_CNO, and G3E_CID key values) inserted into the recordset of each required component.
If the UseLastFeatureAttributes parameter is True (the default value), each new feature has the following characteristics:
A record (initially populated with database default values and the G3E_FNO, G3E_FID, G3E_CNO, and G3E_CID key values) is inserted into the recordset of each required component.
If an input FNO-ClassificationAttributeValue combination has been previously placed or cached, the components of the new feature are populated with additional records so that the number of records in each component matches that of the previous feature. Otherwise, no additional records are created.
For each component record created in the previous step, attribute values are populated in the following order so that subsequent steps overwrite values, including database defaults:
Job classification values are applied.
For attributes defined to be copied, values are copied from components of a previously placed or cached feature having the same FNO-ClassificationAttributeValue combination. The values are copied into the appropriate record by matching the G3E_CNO value. If an input FNO-ClassificationAttributeValue combination has not been placed or cached previously, this step is skipped.
Note:Dialog attribute values do not get applied by this method.
See the Attribute Inheritance and Preloading topic for more details.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.IGTDataContext.NewPlacementConfiguration(System.Int32,System.Boolean,System.Object)
member.summary: Method to create new feature instances with the appropriate defaults for each feature in the placement configuration.
member.param: Placement configuration number.
Determines if attributes are copied from the last placement of a feature whose FNO and ClassificationAttributeValue are the same.

Attribute value that further qualifies the features identified by the input PCNO.
Example:To differentiate a cable feature by its type: coax, wire, or copper.
member.remarks:
DataContext is responsible for caching each new feature's IGTKeyObject until the transaction is committed or rolled back.
This method fails if no transaction is in progress.
The features returned from this method provide important capabilities such as the firing of Functional interfaces and Attribute Edit Control interfaces when edits are made to a component's recordset.
If the UseLastFeatureAttributes parameter is False, each new feature simply has a record (populated with database default values and the G3E_FNO, G3E_FID, G3E_CNO, and G3E_CID key values) inserted into the recordset of each required component.
If the UseLastFeatureAttributes parameter is True (the default value), each new feature has the following characteristics:
A record (initially populated with database default values and the G3E_FNO, G3E_FID, G3E_CNO, and G3E_CID key values) is inserted into the recordset of each required component.
If an input FNO-ClassificationAttributeValue combination has been previously placed or cached, the components of the new feature are populated with additional records so that the number of records in each component matches that of the previous feature. Otherwise, no additional records are created.
For each component record created in the previous step, attribute values are populated in the following order so that subsequent steps overwrite values, including database defaults:
Job classification values are applied.
For attributes defined to be copied, values are copied from components of a previously placed or cached feature having the same FNO-ClassificationAttributeValue combination. The values are copied into the appropriate record by matching the G3E_CNO value. If an input FNO-ClassificationAttributeValue combination has not been placed or cached previously, this step is skipped.
Note:Dialog attribute values do not get applied by this method.
See the Attribute Inheritance and Preloading topic for more details.
